 /><Many courses require you to prepare 'assignments' - writing a report, creating a poster, or doing practical work. If you're new to assignments and don’t know what’s expected of you, it's easy to get worried and stressed. So here we have some tips to reassure you and help you become more confident in tackling assignments. /><Preparing an assignment can feel daunting if you haven't done it before and don't know how to go about it. /><Important: If you're unsure how to prepare your assignment or have other questions, avoid making assumptions or relying on other students for advice. Instead, check your course handbook and ask your lecturer or tutor for information and advice on what they expect from you. /><Here are some quick tips to help you with your assignments: /><•  /><Requirements:  /><Know exactly what's expected regarding scope, word count and deadline. /><•  /><Planning:  /><A good assignment requires advanced planning. Start your research early, collate information and arguments, and don't leave things until the last minute. /><•  /><Writing:  /><If you find it hard to start working on your assignment or get stuck, consider starting with a different part. Just write something – you can always revise and rewrite it later. /><•  /><Structure:  /><Find out how best to structure essays and reports. What’s expected may depend on your course and, to a lesser extent, what your course lead wants you to do. /><Learn more about preparing and writing assignments: /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service.  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Improve your wellbeing and academic performance (2020). Macmillan International Higher Education.  /><www.macmillanihe.com /><•  /><University of Essex.  /><15 foolproof tips for writing a great assignment.  /><online.essex.ac.uk /><•  /><Davey G:  /><The international student's survival guide. Sage publishing.  /><uk.sagepub.com /><
 /><Content last updated: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review to be completed by: March 2026 /><Feedback: To help us improve the app for the benefit of other international students, please send us your comments and suggestions. /><Find contact details and a link to a short anonymous survey on the  /><Feedback page /><. /><Thank you for your help. /><Responsive image /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

If you're new to assignments and don’t know what’s expected of you, it's easy to get worried and stressed. So here we have some tips to reassure you and help you become more confident in tackling assignments. /><Preparing an assignment can feel daunting if you haven't done it before and don't know how to go about it. /><Important: If you're unsure how to prepare your assignment or have other questions, avoid making assumptions or relying on other students for advice. Instead, check your course handbook and ask your lecturer or tutor for information and advice on what they expect from you. /><Here are some quick tips to help you with your assignments: /><•  /><Requirements:  /><Know exactly what's expected regarding scope, word count and deadline. /><•  /><Planning:  /><A good assignment requires advanced planning. Start your research early, collate information and arguments, and don't leave things until the last minute. /><•  /><Writing:  /><If you find it hard to start working on your assignment or get stuck, consider starting with a different part. Just write something – you can always revise and rewrite it later. /><•  /><Structure:  /><Find out how best to structure essays and reports. What’s expected may depend on your course and, to a lesser extent, what your course lead wants you to do. /><Learn more about preparing and writing assignments: /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service.  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Next State: <Navigate up /><Assessments and exams /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><Assessments and exams /><Female student in a black-red chequered shirt writing at a desk with two other students doing the same in the background /><
 /><Assessments - such as exams, essays, group work, portfolios, practical work and presentations - are part of student life. Not surprisingly, they can cause considerable stress and anxiety. So if you feel nervous about assessments and exams, here are some tips for tackling them - and doing well. /><Important: If you fear exams, it can help to know exactly what's expected of you (and what isn’t) and how best to prepare. /><Here are tips for easing your nerves and helping you achieve your best possible grades: /><•  /><Marking:  /><Know what the markings and grades mean to get a realistic picture of what's expected and how you're doing. /><•  /><Revision:  /><Consider revising in various locations, so you won't find being in a new setting for the exam too unsettling. /><•  /><Plan:  /><Decide early on what you're going to revise, and how you're going to do it. /><•  /><Technique:  /><Consider various revision methods, such as revision cards, mind maps, and doing past papers. Try different strategies and use what works best for you. /><•  /><Noise:  /><Spend time revising in situations with background noise, like the campus restaurant. This will train your brain to function despite distractions. /><•  /><Sleep:  /><Ensure you sleep enough before the exam and avoid last-minute revision late at night. /><•  /><Food:  /><Eat healthily and avoid junk food. A balanced diet, including fresh fruit and vegetables, will help to give you focus and energy. /><•  /><Focus:  /><Avoid getting negatively distracted by what other people are doing and saying before the exam. /><•  /><Relaxation:  /><If you feel anxious before or during exams, try relaxation techniques (see the 'Support' section - accessible from the homepage - for more info). /><•  /><Physical activity:  /><Include physical activity in your daily and weekly routines. It's a good de-stressor and will help to make your revision more effective. /><•  /><Staying positive:  /><Don’t let bad days (we all have them) affect you. Don't let exams stress you too much! /><Important: If you're struggling with assessments or exams and feel overwhelmed, overly stressed or physically unwell, speak with your lecturer, tutor, student support team, or doctor (GP). Also, let them know if there's anything else going on in your life that may affect your performance or ability to take part (such as family problems or financial difficulties). They will do what they can to help and won't judge you. /><Learn more about how to do well in your assessments and exams: /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS).  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for Success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Exam stress.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Staying well and safe at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Improve your wellbeing and academic performance (2020). Macmillan International Higher Education.  /><www.macmillanihe.com /><•  /><Davey G.  /><The international student's survival guide.  /><Assessments - such as exams, essays, group work, portfolios, practical work and presentations - are part of student life. Not surprisingly, they can cause considerable stress and anxiety. So if you feel nervous about assessments and exams, here are some tips for tackling them - and doing well. /><Important: If you fear exams, it can help to know exactly what's expected of you (and what isn’t) and how best to prepare. /><Here are tips for easing your nerves and helping you achieve your best possible grades: /><•  /><Marking:  /><Know what the markings and grades mean to get a realistic picture of what's expected and how you're doing. /><•  /><Revision:  /><Consider revising in various locations, so you won't find being in a new setting for the exam too unsettling. /><•  /><Plan:  /><Decide early on what you're going to revise, and how you're going to do it. /><•  /><Technique:  /><Consider various revision methods, such as revision cards, mind maps, and doing past papers. Try different strategies and use what works best for you. /><•  /><Noise:  /><Spend time revising in situations with background noise, like the campus restaurant. This will train your brain to function despite distractions. /><•  /><Sleep:  /><Ensure you sleep enough before the exam and avoid last-minute revision late at night. /><•  /><Food:  /><Eat healthily and avoid junk food. A balanced diet, including fresh fruit and vegetables, will help to give you focus and energy. /><•  /><Focus:  /><Avoid getting negatively distracted by what other people are doing and saying before the exam. /><•  /><Relaxation:  /><If you feel anxious before or during exams, try relaxation techniques (see the 'Support' section - accessible from the homepage - for more info). /><•  /><Physical activity:  /><Include physical activity in your daily and weekly routines. It's a good de-stressor and will help to make your revision more effective. /><•  /><Staying positive:  /><Don’t let bad days (we all have them) affect you. Don't let exams stress you too much! /><Important: If you're struggling with assessments or exams and feel overwhelmed, overly stressed or physically unwell, speak with your lecturer, tutor, student support team, or doctor (GP). Also, let them know if there's anything else going on in your life that may affect your performance or ability to take part (such as family problems or financial difficulties). They will do what they can to help and won't judge you. /><Learn more about how to do well in your assessments and exams: /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS).  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for Success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Exam stress.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university.  /><Plagiarism is when you use the words or ideas of someone without giving the source or presenting another person’s work as your own. If you’re found guilty of plagiarism, it can have severe consequences - including failing your course. So on this page, we outline issues around plagiarism and give tips for avoiding it. /><UK universities treat plagiarism as a serious issue and regard it as 'academic misconduct', similar to cheating or fabricating results. /><Important: Be aware that penalties for plagiarism can be severe. This could mean zero marks for an exam or even failing your course. Lecturers are experienced in spotting plagiarism and may use software to detect it. /><So you must understand what plagiarism means and how to avoid it. If you have questions, check out the resources below or ask your tutor. /><Here are tips for avoiding plagiarism: /><•  /><Quotations:  /><If you quote from a book or mention someone else's idea – even if you use your own words – you need to specify the source. Always use quotation marks for directly quoting even small amounts of text. /><•  /><Sources:  /><Use a variety of sources to show you've read widely. /><•  /><Personal views:  /><Show that you have formulated your own opinions based on what you've read. /><•  /><Personal style:  /><Develop your own style of writing over time, so you don't rely on the words of other people. /><•  /><Referencing:  /><Find out how exactly to reference your sources. Refer to your university's guidance and speak with your tutor if unsure. /><Learn more about plagiarism: /><•  /><Plagiarism.  /><Understanding plagiarism.  /><www.plagiarism.org /><•  /><Prepare for success.  /><Using what you read in academic writing.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Improve your wellbeing and academic performance (2020). Macmillan International Higher Education.  /><www.macmillanihe.com /><

 /><Many courses require you to prepare 'assignments' - writing a report, creating a poster, or doing practical work. If you're new to assignments and don’t know what’s expected of you, it's easy to get worried and stressed. So here we have some tips to reassure you and help you become more confident in tackling assignments. /><Preparing an assignment can feel daunting if you haven't done it before and don't know how to go about it. /><Important: If you're unsure how to prepare your assignment or have other questions, avoid making assumptions or relying on other students for advice. Instead, check your course handbook and ask your lecturer or tutor for information and advice on what they expect from you. /><Here are some quick tips to help you with your assignments: /><•  /><Requirements:  /><Know exactly what's expected regarding scope, word count and deadline. /><•  /><Planning:  /><A good assignment requires advanced planning. Start your research early, collate information and arguments, and don't leave things until the last minute. /><•  /><Writing:  /><If you find it hard to start working on your assignment or get stuck, consider starting with a different part. Just write something – you can always revise and rewrite it later. /><•  /><Structure:  /><Find out how best to structure essays and reports. What’s expected may depend on your course and, to a lesser extent, what your course lead wants you to do. /><Learn more about preparing and writing assignments: /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service.  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Improve your wellbeing and academic performance (2020). Round 3: State: <Navigate up /><Assessments and exams /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><Assessments and exams /><Female student in a black-red chequered shirt writing at a desk with two other students doing the same in the background /><
 /><Assessments - such as exams, essays, group work, portfolios, practical work and presentations - are part of student life. Not surprisingly, they can cause considerable stress and anxiety. So if you feel nervous about assessments and exams, here are some tips for tackling them - and doing well. /><Important: If you fear exams, it can help to know exactly what's expected of you (and what isn’t) and how best to prepare. /><Here are tips for easing your nerves and helping you achieve your best possible grades: /><•  /><Marking:  /><Know what the markings and grades mean to get a realistic picture of what's expected and how you're doing. /><•  /><Revision:  /><Consider revising in various locations, so you won't find being in a new setting for the exam too unsettling. /><•  /><Plan:  /><Decide early on what you're going to revise, and how you're going to do it. /><•  /><Technique:  /><Consider various revision methods, such as revision cards, mind maps, and doing past papers. Try different strategies and use what works best for you. /><•  /><Noise:  /><Spend time revising in situations with background noise, like the campus restaurant. This will train your brain to function despite distractions. /><•  /><Sleep:  /><Ensure you sleep enough before the exam and avoid last-minute revision late at night. /><•  /><Food:  /><Eat healthily and avoid junk food. A balanced diet, including fresh fruit and vegetables, will help to give you focus and energy. /><•  /><Focus:  /><Avoid getting negatively distracted by what other people are doing and saying before the exam. /><•  /><Relaxation:  /><If you feel anxious before or during exams, try relaxation techniques (see the 'Support' section - accessible from the homepage - for more info). /><•  /><Physical activity:  /><Include physical activity in your daily and weekly routines. It's a good de-stressor and will help to make your revision more effective. /><•  /><Staying positive:  /><Don’t let bad days (we all have them) affect you. Don't let exams stress you too much! /><Important: If you're struggling with assessments or exams and feel overwhelmed, overly stressed or physically unwell, speak with your lecturer, tutor, student support team, or doctor (GP). Also, let them know if there's anything else going on in your life that may affect your performance or ability to take part (such as family problems or financial difficulties). They will do what they can to help and won't judge you. /><Learn more about how to do well in your assessments and exams: /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS).  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for Success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Exam stress.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Staying well and safe at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Round 4: State: <Navigate up /><Plagiarism /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><Plagiarism /><Scene inside a library with students working, sitteing at desks, and standing next to each other talking /><
 /><Plagiarism is when you use the words or ideas of someone without giving the source or presenting another person’s work as your own. If you’re found guilty of plagiarism, it can have severe consequences - including failing your course. So on this page, we outline issues around plagiarism and give tips for avoiding it. /><UK universities treat plagiarism as a serious issue and regard it as 'academic misconduct', similar to cheating or fabricating results. /><Important: Be aware that penalties for plagiarism can be severe. This could mean zero marks for an exam or even failing your course. Lecturers are experienced in spotting plagiarism and may use software to detect it. /><So you must understand what plagiarism means and how to avoid it. If you have questions, check out the resources below or ask your tutor. /><Here are tips for avoiding plagiarism: /><•  /><Quotations:  /><If you quote from a book or mention someone else's idea – even if you use your own words – you need to specify the source. Always use quotation marks for directly quoting even small amounts of text. /><•  /><Sources:  /><Use a variety of sources to show you've read widely. /><•  /><Personal views:  /><Show that you have formulated your own opinions based on what you've read. /><•  /><Personal style:  /><Develop your own style of writing over time, so you don't rely on the words of other people. /><•  /><Referencing:  /><Find out how exactly to reference your sources. Refer to your university's guidance and speak with your tutor if unsure. /><Learn more about plagiarism: /><•  /><Plagiarism.  /><Understanding plagiarism.  /><www.plagiarism.org /><•  /><Prepare for success.  /><Using what you read in academic writing.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Improve your wellbeing and academic performance (2020). Macmillan International Higher Education.  /><www.macmillanihe.com /><

 /><Many courses require you to prepare 'assignments' - writing a report, creating a poster, or doing practical work. If you're new to assignments and don’t know what’s expected of you, it's easy to get worried and stressed. So here we have some tips to reassure you and help you become more confident in tackling assignments. /><Preparing an assignment can feel daunting if you haven't done it before and don't know how to go about it. /><Important: If you're unsure how to prepare your assignment or have other questions, avoid making assumptions or relying on other students for advice. Instead, check your course handbook and ask your lecturer or tutor for information and advice on what they expect from you. /><Here are some quick tips to help you with your assignments: /><•  /><Requirements:  /><Know exactly what's expected regarding scope, word count and deadline. /><•  /><Planning:  /><A good assignment requires advanced planning. Start your research early, collate information and arguments, and don't leave things until the last minute. /><•  /><Writing:  /><If you find it hard to start working on your assignment or get stuck, consider starting with a different part. Just write something – you can always revise and rewrite it later. /><•  /><Structure:  /><Find out how best to structure essays and reports. What’s expected may depend on your course and, to a lesser extent, what your course lead wants you to do. /><Learn more about preparing and writing assignments: /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service.  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Improve your wellbeing and academic performance (2020). Macmillan International Higher Education.  /><www.macmillanihe.com /><•  /><University of Essex.  /><15 foolproof tips for writing a great assignment.  /><online.essex.ac.uk /><•  /><Davey G:  /><The international student's survival guide. Round 2: State: <Navigate up /><Assessments and exams /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><Assessments and exams /><Female student in a black-red chequered shirt writing at a desk with two other students doing the same in the background /><
 /><Assessments - such as exams, essays, group work, portfolios, practical work and presentations - are part of student life. Not surprisingly, they can cause considerable stress and anxiety. So if you feel nervous about assessments and exams, here are some tips for tackling them - and doing well. /><Important: If you fear exams, it can help to know exactly what's expected of you (and what isn’t) and how best to prepare. /><Here are tips for easing your nerves and helping you achieve your best possible grades: /><•  /><Marking:  /><Know what the markings and grades mean to get a realistic picture of what's expected and how you're doing. /><•  /><Revision:  /><Consider revising in various locations, so you won't find being in a new setting for the exam too unsettling. /><•  /><Plan:  /><Decide early on what you're going to revise, and how you're going to do it. /><•  /><Technique:  /><Consider various revision methods, such as revision cards, mind maps, and doing past papers. Try different strategies and use what works best for you. /><•  /><Noise:  /><Spend time revising in situations with background noise, like the campus restaurant. This will train your brain to function despite distractions. /><•  /><Sleep:  /><Ensure you sleep enough before the exam and avoid last-minute revision late at night. /><•  /><Food:  /><Eat healthily and avoid junk food. A balanced diet, including fresh fruit and vegetables, will help to give you focus and energy. /><•  /><Focus:  /><Avoid getting negatively distracted by what other people are doing and saying before the exam. /><•  /><Relaxation:  /><If you feel anxious before or during exams, try relaxation techniques (see the 'Support' section - accessible from the homepage - for more info). /><•  /><Physical activity:  /><Include physical activity in your daily and weekly routines. It's a good de-stressor and will help to make your revision more effective. /><•  /><Staying positive:  /><Don’t let bad days (we all have them) affect you. Don't let exams stress you too much! /><Important: If you're struggling with assessments or exams and feel overwhelmed, overly stressed or physically unwell, speak with your lecturer, tutor, student support team, or doctor (GP). Also, let them know if there's anything else going on in your life that may affect your performance or ability to take part (such as family problems or financial difficulties). They will do what they can to help and won't judge you. /><Learn more about how to do well in your assessments and exams: /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS).  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for Success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Exam stress.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university.  /><Plagiarism is when you use the words or ideas of someone without giving the source or presenting another person’s work as your own. If you’re found guilty of plagiarism, it can have severe consequences - including failing your course. So on this page, we outline issues around plagiarism and give tips for avoiding it. /><UK universities treat plagiarism as a serious issue and regard it as 'academic misconduct', similar to cheating or fabricating results. /><Important: Be aware that penalties for plagiarism can be severe. This could mean zero marks for an exam or even failing your course. Lecturers are experienced in spotting plagiarism and may use software to detect it. /><So you must understand what plagiarism means and how to avoid it. If you have questions, check out the resources below or ask your tutor. /><Here are tips for avoiding plagiarism: /><•  /><Quotations:  /><If you quote from a book or mention someone else's idea – even if you use your own words – you need to specify the source. Always use quotation marks for directly quoting even small amounts of text. /><•  /><Sources:  /><Use a variety of sources to show you've read widely. /><•  /><Personal views:  /><Show that you have formulated your own opinions based on what you've read. /><•  /><Personal style:  /><Develop your own style of writing over time, so you don't rely on the words of other people. /><•  /><Referencing:  /><Find out how exactly to reference your sources. Refer to your university's guidance and speak with your tutor if unsure. /><Learn more about plagiarism: /><•  /><Plagiarism.  /><Understanding plagiarism.  /><www.plagiarism.org /><•  /><Prepare for success.  /><Using what you read in academic writing.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. This will train your brain to function despite distractions. /><•  /><Sleep:  /><Ensure you sleep enough before the exam and avoid last-minute revision late at night. /><•  /><Food:  /><Eat healthily and avoid junk food. A balanced diet, including fresh fruit and vegetables, will help to give you focus and energy. /><•  /><Focus:  /><Avoid getting negatively distracted by what other people are doing and saying before the exam. /><•  /><Relaxation:  /><If you feel anxious before or during exams, try relaxation techniques (see the 'Support' section - accessible from the homepage - for more info). /><•  /><Physical activity:  /><Include physical activity in your daily and weekly routines. It's a good de-stressor and will help to make your revision more effective. /><•  /><Staying positive:  /><Don’t let bad days (we all have them) affect you. Don't let exams stress you too much! /><Important: If you're struggling with assessments or exams and feel overwhelmed, overly stressed or physically unwell, speak with your lecturer, tutor, student support team, or doctor (GP). Also, let them know if there's anything else going on in your life that may affect your performance or ability to take part (such as family problems or financial difficulties). They will do what they can to help and won't judge you. /><Learn more about how to do well in your assessments and exams: /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS).  /><Study skills guides.  /><www.ucas.com /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Study and assessment methods.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Prepare for Success.  /><Learning activities to prepare you for study in the UK.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Exam stress.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university.  /><Plagiarism is when you use the words or ideas of someone without giving the source or presenting another person’s work as your own. If you’re found guilty of plagiarism, it can have severe consequences - including failing your course. So on this page, we outline issues around plagiarism and give tips for avoiding it. /><UK universities treat plagiarism as a serious issue and regard it as 'academic misconduct', similar to cheating or fabricating results. /><Important: Be aware that penalties for plagiarism can be severe. This could mean zero marks for an exam or even failing your course. Lecturers are experienced in spotting plagiarism and may use software to detect it. /><So you must understand what plagiarism means and how to avoid it. If you have questions, check out the resources below or ask your tutor. /><Here are tips for avoiding plagiarism: /><•  /><Quotations:  /><If you quote from a book or mention someone else's idea – even if you use your own words – you need to specify the source. Always use quotation marks for directly quoting even small amounts of text. /><•  /><Sources:  /><Use a variety of sources to show you've read widely. /><•  /><Personal views:  /><Show that you have formulated your own opinions based on what you've read. /><•  /><Personal style:  /><Develop your own style of writing over time, so you don't rely on the words of other people. /><•  /><Referencing:  /><Find out how exactly to reference your sources. Refer to your university's guidance and speak with your tutor if unsure. /><Learn more about plagiarism: /><•  /><Plagiarism.  /><Understanding plagiarism.  /><www.plagiarism.org /><•  /><Prepare for success.  /><Using what you read in academic writing.  /><www.prepareforsuccess.org.uk /><•  /><Hughes G.  /><Be well, learn well. Next State: <Navigate up /><What to pack /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><What to pack /><Student sitting on floor while packing /><
 /><When you're getting ready to move to the UK, it can be hard to know what to pack. What’s more, it’s easy to forget key items or accidentally bring things that are not allowed in the UK. Here are tips and suggestions for deciding what to take, plus links to more information if you need more detail. /><Consider only packing the things you need for your first few weeks. /><If you travel to the UK by air, don’t forget that most airlines have weight restrictions for check-in luggage and cabin bags unless you pay extra. /><Here's a video by Karen Acosta, a student at the University of Lincoln, with tips on what to pack: /><
 /><YouTube></YouTube><
 /><Important: Remember there are limits to what you can take into the UK, including alcohol, cigarettes and gifts. To stay on the right side of the law and avoid getting into trouble, never bring fake goods, illegal drugs, offensive weapons or indecent materials into the UK. /><The video below on UK Customs Information has further details. /><
 /><
 /><Here's a quick checklist of items to take for your journey and arrival: /><•  /><Passport:  /><Make sure it's valid and that you have a visa if required. /><•  /><Ticket:  /><Ensure you have your plane, train or ferry tickets to hand. /><•  /><Money:  /><Consider ordering British currency or travellers' cheques in advance and have these on you when you travel. Take enough money (about £250) for travel, food, essentials and emergency expenses. Also, make sure you have enough cash immediately available to cover a deposit for your accommodation (if needed), which you may have to pay before you move in (usually about one month's rent, but it can be more). /><•  /><Contact details:  /><Have essential contact details (accommodation, International Student Office, University Security) readily accessible. /><•  /><Medicines:  /><If you take regular medicines, take at least a two-month supply (ideally more) to tie you over until you've registered with a local doctor (GP). Also, bring a note from your doctor explaining what medicines you take, what they're for, and how long you should take them (translated into English). /><•  /><Items for your room:  /><Consider taking small things to you feel at home in your new accommodation, such as photos of family and friends and items of personal value. /><•  /><Adaptors:  /><Consider buying adaptors for your electronic gadgets (such as a phone charger) before you enter the UK or on arrival because the power sockets in the UK will likely differ from those at home. /><Avoid bringing the following: /><•  /><Huge suitcase:  /><Airlines will only allow you to check-in between 20 to 30 kg if you have an economy class ticket, though you can pay for excess baggage. Remember that a large-size suitcase may be challenging to handle on public transport or if you move into accommodation without an elevator. You may also find it difficult to store large suitcases in your room. /><•  /><Winter clothing:  /><Winter clothes can be bulky and heavy and take up a lot of space in your suitcase. You may prefer to buy them in the UK after your arrival. Local department stores or second-hand shops offer winter clothing to suit most budgets. Bring various layers of clothes to keep you warm on and after arrival. /><•  /><Textbooks:  /><You'll unlikely need to read - or buy - every book on your reading list before you arrive. Many titles will be available at your library, or you can buy them second-hand, saving you money too. /><•  /><Homeware:  /><Consider buying cooking utensils, cutlery, bedding and clothes hangers after you arrive. You can get them in department stores, local shops, second-hand from other students, or even for free through apps such as  /><Olio /><or  /><Gumtree /><. /><To learn more about what you can bring into the UK visit: /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Border Force.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Bringing goods into the UK for personal use.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Entering the UK.  /><www.gov.uk /><

 /><When you're getting ready to move to the UK, it can be hard to know what to pack. What’s more, it’s easy to forget key items or accidentally bring things that are not allowed in the UK. Here are tips and suggestions for deciding what to take, plus links to more information if you need more detail. /><Consider only packing the things you need for your first few weeks. /><If you travel to the UK by air, don’t forget that most airlines have weight restrictions for check-in luggage and cabin bags unless you pay extra. /><Here's a video by Karen Acosta, a student at the University of Lincoln, with tips on what to pack: /><
 /><YouTube></YouTube><
 /><Important: Remember there are limits to what you can take into the UK, including alcohol, cigarettes and gifts. To stay on the right side of the law and avoid getting into trouble, never bring fake goods, illegal drugs, offensive weapons or indecent materials into the UK. /><The video below on UK Customs Information has further details. /><
 /><
 /><Here's a quick checklist of items to take for your journey and arrival: /><•  /><Passport:  /><Make sure it's valid and that you have a visa if required. /><•  /><Ticket:  /><Ensure you have your plane, train or ferry tickets to hand. /><•  /><Money:  /><Consider ordering British currency or travellers' cheques in advance and have these on you when you travel. Take enough money (about £250) for travel, food, essentials and emergency expenses. Also, make sure you have enough cash immediately available to cover a deposit for your accommodation (if needed), which you may have to pay before you move in (usually about one month's rent, but it can be more). /><•  /><Contact details:  /><Have essential contact details (accommodation, International Student Office, University Security) readily accessible. /><•  /><Medicines:  /><If you take regular medicines, take at least a two-month supply (ideally more) to tie you over until you've registered with a local doctor (GP). Also, bring a note from your doctor explaining what medicines you take, what they're for, and how long you should take them (translated into English). /><•  /><Items for your room:  /><Consider taking small things to you feel at home in your new accommodation, such as photos of family and friends and items of personal value. /><•  /><Adaptors:  /><Consider buying adaptors for your electronic gadgets (such as a phone charger) before you enter the UK or on arrival because the power sockets in the UK will likely differ from those at home. /><Avoid bringing the following: /><•  /><Huge suitcase:  /><Airlines will only allow you to check-in between 20 to 30 kg if you have an economy class ticket, though you can pay for excess baggage. Remember that a large-size suitcase may be challenging to handle on public transport or if you move into accommodation without an elevator. You may also find it difficult to store large suitcases in your room. /><•  /><Winter clothing:  /><Winter clothes can be bulky and heavy and take up a lot of space in your suitcase. You may prefer to buy them in the UK after your arrival. Local department stores or second-hand shops offer winter clothing to suit most budgets. Bring various layers of clothes to keep you warm on and after arrival. /><•  /><Textbooks:  /><You'll unlikely need to read - or buy - every book on your reading list before you arrive. Many titles will be available at your library, or you can buy them second-hand, saving you money too. /><•  /><Homeware:  /><Consider buying cooking utensils, cutlery, bedding and clothes hangers after you arrive. You can get them in department stores, local shops, second-hand from other students, or even for free through apps such as  /><Olio /><or  /><Gumtree /><. /><To learn more about what you can bring into the UK visit: /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Border Force.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Bringing goods into the UK for personal use.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Entering the UK.  /><www.gov.uk /><
 /><Content last updated: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review to be completed by: March 2026 /><Feedback: To help us improve the app for the benefit of other international students, please send us your comments and suggestions. /><Find contact details and a link to a short anonymous survey on the  /><Feedback page /><. /><Thank you for your help. /><Responsive image /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><When you're getting ready to move to the UK, it can be hard to know what to pack. What’s more, it’s easy to forget key items or accidentally bring things that are not allowed in the UK. Here are tips and suggestions for deciding what to take, plus links to more information if you need more detail. /><Consider only packing the things you need for your first few weeks. /><If you travel to the UK by air, don’t forget that most airlines have weight restrictions for check-in luggage and cabin bags unless you pay extra. /><Here's a video by Karen Acosta, a student at the University of Lincoln, with tips on what to pack: /><
 /><YouTube></YouTube><
 /><Important: Remember there are limits to what you can take into the UK, including alcohol, cigarettes and gifts. To stay on the right side of the law and avoid getting into trouble, never bring fake goods, illegal drugs, offensive weapons or indecent materials into the UK. /><The video below on UK Customs Information has further details. /><
 /><
 /><Here's a quick checklist of items to take for your journey and arrival: /><•  /><Passport:  /><Make sure it's valid and that you have a visa if required. /><•  /><Ticket:  /><Ensure you have your plane, train or ferry tickets to hand. /><•  /><Money:  /><Consider ordering British currency or travellers' cheques in advance and have these on you when you travel. Take enough money (about £250) for travel, food, essentials and emergency expenses. Also, make sure you have enough cash immediately available to cover a deposit for your accommodation (if needed), which you may have to pay before you move in (usually about one month's rent, but it can be more). /><•  /><Contact details:  /><Have essential contact details (accommodation, International Student Office, University Security) readily accessible. /><•  /><Medicines:  /><If you take regular medicines, take at least a two-month supply (ideally more) to tie you over until you've registered with a local doctor (GP). Also, bring a note from your doctor explaining what medicines you take, what they're for, and how long you should take them (translated into English). /><•  /><Items for your room:  /><Consider taking small things to you feel at home in your new accommodation, such as photos of family and friends and items of personal value. /><•  /><Adaptors:  /><Consider buying adaptors for your electronic gadgets (such as a phone charger) before you enter the UK or on arrival because the power sockets in the UK will likely differ from those at home. /><Avoid bringing the following: /><•  /><Huge suitcase:  /><Airlines will only allow you to check-in between 20 to 30 kg if you have an economy class ticket, though you can pay for excess baggage. Remember that a large-size suitcase may be challenging to handle on public transport or if you move into accommodation without an elevator. You may also find it difficult to store large suitcases in your room. /><•  /><Winter clothing:  /><Winter clothes can be bulky and heavy and take up a lot of space in your suitcase. You may prefer to buy them in the UK after your arrival. Local department stores or second-hand shops offer winter clothing to suit most budgets. Bring various layers of clothes to keep you warm on and after arrival. /><•  /><Textbooks:  /><You'll unlikely need to read - or buy - every book on your reading list before you arrive. Many titles will be available at your library, or you can buy them second-hand, saving you money too. /><•  /><Homeware:  /><Consider buying cooking utensils, cutlery, bedding and clothes hangers after you arrive. You can get them in department stores, local shops, second-hand from other students, or even for free through apps such as  /><Olio /><or  /><Gumtree /><. /><To learn more about what you can bring into the UK visit: /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Border Force.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Bringing goods into the UK for personal use.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Entering the UK.  /><www.gov.uk /><
 /><Content last updated: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review to be completed by: March 2026 /><Feedback: To help us improve the app for the benefit of other international students, please send us your comments and suggestions. /><Find contact details and a link to a short anonymous survey on the  /><Feedback page /><. /><Thank you for your help. /><Responsive image /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><Feeling stressed, exhausted, or overwhelmed can make coping with everyday life and your studies difficult. Such feelings have to do with your mental health. Here we explain briefly what good mental health is and how to get support if needed. /><Good mental health involves feeling good about yourself and others, forming and maintaining healthy relationships, and being able to deal with - and overcome - challenges. /><When your mental health is poor, you may find it hard, or even impossible, to manage how you feel, think and act in response to emotional or other stresses. /><Important: If you feel anxious, low, panicky, isolated, stressed, lonely, homesick, overwhelmed or even suicidal (feeling so bad that you think life's not worth living anymore), remember that there are people at your university who understand, won’t judge, care about you, and want to do their best to help and support you (see below). It's perfectly okay to seek help when you need it. Together you can find solutions to improve your overall wellbeing and reduce any negative impact on your studies. /><Get help for mental health issues: /><•  /><Student support:  /><Your university will likely have a student wellbeing and welfare department whom you can ask for help, advice and assistance confidentially (which means they won't tell anyone else). Check your uni’s website or ask the international office for information about accessing these services. /><•  /><Outside organisations:  /><If you prefer to speak with someone from outside your university, various organisations are there to help (see links below). /><•  /><Your doctor (GP):  /><You can also speak with your GP about mental health issues - in confidence. /><If you're worried about a friend’s mental health, find advice on the  /><'Supporting a friend' /><page. /><Learn more about mental health and getting support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><The UK's student mental health charity.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Challenging mental health myths for international students.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Mental health support in the UK.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Staying well and safe at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Mind.  /><The mental health charity.  /><www.mind.org.uk /><•  /><NHS Website.  /><Counselling for student mental health problems.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><Nightline.  /><Confidential, anonymous and non-judgemental support service, run by students for students.  /><www.nightline.ac.uk /><•  /><Students Against Depression.  /><Self-help resources.  /><www.studentsagainstdepression.org /><

 /><Feeling stressed, exhausted, or overwhelmed can make coping with everyday life and your studies difficult. Such feelings have to do with your mental health. Here we explain briefly what good mental health is and how to get support if needed. /><Good mental health involves feeling good about yourself and others, forming and maintaining healthy relationships, and being able to deal with - and overcome - challenges. /><When your mental health is poor, you may find it hard, or even impossible, to manage how you feel, think and act in response to emotional or other stresses. /><Important: If you feel anxious, low, panicky, isolated, stressed, lonely, homesick, overwhelmed or even suicidal (feeling so bad that you think life's not worth living anymore), remember that there are people at your university who understand, won’t judge, care about you, and want to do their best to help and support you (see below). It's perfectly okay to seek help when you need it. Together you can find solutions to improve your overall wellbeing and reduce any negative impact on your studies. /><Get help for mental health issues: /><•  /><Student support:  /><Your university will likely have a student wellbeing and welfare department whom you can ask for help, advice and assistance confidentially (which means they won't tell anyone else). Check your uni’s website or ask the international office for information about accessing these services. /><•  /><Outside organisations:  /><If you prefer to speak with someone from outside your university, various organisations are there to help (see links below). /><•  /><Your doctor (GP):  /><You can also speak with your GP about mental health issues - in confidence. /><If you're worried about a friend’s mental health, find advice on the  /><'Supporting a friend' /><page. /><Learn more about mental health and getting support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><The UK's student mental health charity.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Challenging mental health myths for international students.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Mental health support in the UK.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Staying well and safe at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Mind.  /><The mental health charity.  /><www.mind.org.uk /><•  /><NHS Website.  /><Counselling for student mental health problems.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><Nightline.  /><Confidential, anonymous and non-judgemental support service, run by students for students.  /><www.nightline.ac.uk /><•  /><Students Against Depression.  /><Self-help resources.  /><www.studentsagainstdepression.org /><

App Name: International Student App (UK)
App Description: Designed to help international students in the UK manage their studies and life, offering visa info, events, and campus resources.

State-Action History:
Round 0: State: <Navigate up /><GET READY /><Coronavirus guidance at uni /><Preparing for your new life /><Your university experience /><Pre-enrolment-courses /><Getting to know your university /><Visa and immigration issues /><Learning basic life skills /><Health, disability and support /><Key documents /><Cost of maintenance /><What to pack />
 Action: touch:<What to pack />
Round 1: State: <Navigate up /><What to pack /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><What to pack /><Student sitting on floor while packing /><
 /><When you're getting ready to move to the UK, it can be hard to know what to pack. What’s more, it’s easy to forget key items or accidentally bring things that are not allowed in the UK. Here are tips and suggestions for deciding what to take, plus links to more information if you need more detail. /><Consider only packing the things you need for your first few weeks. /><If you travel to the UK by air, don’t forget that most airlines have weight restrictions for check-in luggage and cabin bags unless you pay extra. /><Here's a video by Karen Acosta, a student at the University of Lincoln, with tips on what to pack: /><
 /><YouTube></YouTube><
 /><Important: Remember there are limits to what you can take into the UK, including alcohol, cigarettes and gifts. To stay on the right side of the law and avoid getting into trouble, never bring fake goods, illegal drugs, offensive weapons or indecent materials into the UK. /><The video below on UK Customs Information has further details. /><
 /><
 /><Here's a quick checklist of items to take for your journey and arrival: /><•  /><Passport:  /><Make sure it's valid and that you have a visa if required. /><•  /><Ticket:  /><Ensure you have your plane, train or ferry tickets to hand. /><•  /><Money:  /><Consider ordering British currency or travellers' cheques in advance and have these on you when you travel. Take enough money (about £250) for travel, food, essentials and emergency expenses. Also, make sure you have enough cash immediately available to cover a deposit for your accommodation (if needed), which you may have to pay before you move in (usually about one month's rent, but it can be more). /><•  /><Contact details:  /><Have essential contact details (accommodation, International Student Office, University Security) readily accessible. /><•  /><Medicines:  /><If you take regular medicines, take at least a two-month supply (ideally more) to tie you over until you've registered with a local doctor (GP). Also, bring a note from your doctor explaining what medicines you take, what they're for, and how long you should take them (translated into English). /><•  /><Items for your room:  /><Consider taking small things to you feel at home in your new accommodation, such as photos of family and friends and items of personal value. /><•  /><Adaptors:  /><Consider buying adaptors for your electronic gadgets (such as a phone charger) before you enter the UK or on arrival because the power sockets in the UK will likely differ from those at home. /><Avoid bringing the following: /><•  /><Huge suitcase:  /><Airlines will only allow you to check-in between 20 to 30 kg if you have an economy class ticket, though you can pay for excess baggage. Remember that a large-size suitcase may be challenging to handle on public transport or if you move into accommodation without an elevator. You may also find it difficult to store large suitcases in your room. /><•  /><Winter clothing:  /><Winter clothes can be bulky and heavy and take up a lot of space in your suitcase. You may prefer to buy them in the UK after your arrival. Local department stores or second-hand shops offer winter clothing to suit most budgets. Bring various layers of clothes to keep you warm on and after arrival. /><•  /><Textbooks:  /><You'll unlikely need to read - or buy - every book on your reading list before you arrive. Many titles will be available at your library, or you can buy them second-hand, saving you money too. /><•  /><Homeware:  /><Consider buying cooking utensils, cutlery, bedding and clothes hangers after you arrive. You can get them in department stores, local shops, second-hand from other students, or even for free through apps such as  /><Olio /><or  /><Gumtree /><. /><To learn more about what you can bring into the UK visit: /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Border Force.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Bringing goods into the UK for personal use.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Entering the UK.  /><www.gov.uk /><
 /><Content last updated: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review to be completed by: March 2026 /><Feedback: To help us improve the app for the benefit of other international students, please send us your comments and suggestions. /><Find contact details and a link to a short anonymous survey on the  /><Feedback page /><. /><Thank you for your help. /><Responsive image /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

Bring various layers of clothes to keep you warm on and after arrival. /><•  /><Textbooks:  /><You'll unlikely need to read - or buy - every book on your reading list before you arrive. Many titles will be available at your library, or you can buy them second-hand, saving you money too. /><•  /><Homeware:  /><Consider buying cooking utensils, cutlery, bedding and clothes hangers after you arrive. You can get them in department stores, local shops, second-hand from other students, or even for free through apps such as  /><Olio /><or  /><Gumtree /><. /><To learn more about what you can bring into the UK visit: /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Border Force.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Bringing goods into the UK for personal use.  /><www.gov.uk /><•  /><UK Government website.  /><Entering the UK.  /><www.gov.uk /><

 /><Feeling stressed, exhausted, or overwhelmed can make coping with everyday life and your studies difficult. Such feelings have to do with your mental health. Here we explain briefly what good mental health is and how to get support if needed. /><Good mental health involves feeling good about yourself and others, forming and maintaining healthy relationships, and being able to deal with - and overcome - challenges. /><When your mental health is poor, you may find it hard, or even impossible, to manage how you feel, think and act in response to emotional or other stresses. /><Important: If you feel anxious, low, panicky, isolated, stressed, lonely, homesick, overwhelmed or even suicidal (feeling so bad that you think life's not worth living anymore), remember that there are people at your university who understand, won’t judge, care about you, and want to do their best to help and support you (see below). It's perfectly okay to seek help when you need it. Together you can find solutions to improve your overall wellbeing and reduce any negative impact on your studies. /><Get help for mental health issues: /><•  /><Student support:  /><Your university will likely have a student wellbeing and welfare department whom you can ask for help, advice and assistance confidentially (which means they won't tell anyone else). Check your uni’s website or ask the international office for information about accessing these services. /><•  /><Outside organisations:  /><If you prefer to speak with someone from outside your university, various organisations are there to help (see links below). /><•  /><Your doctor (GP):  /><You can also speak with your GP about mental health issues - in confidence. /><If you're worried about a friend’s mental health, find advice on the  /><'Supporting a friend' /><page. /><Learn more about mental health and getting support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><The UK's student mental health charity.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Challenging mental health myths for international students.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Mental health support in the UK.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university.  /><If you need help or want to speak with someone about personal issues, your course or your health, your university or college offers various support services. Here we outline how these services can help and include useful links. /><Available services usually include (but may be called differently): /><•  /><Student Support (or Wellbeing)Service /><•  /><International Student Support team /><•  /><Students' Union /><•  /><University Medical (GP) Practice /><These services have trained advisers and professionals who are there to support and guide you (see below). /><You can find details about accessing support on your university’s and Students' Union’s websites. /><Important: Student support staff won't judge you, and they will keep what you tell them in strict confidence. They will understand your feelings, care about you, and want to do their best to support you. /><Your local student support teams can help you with things like: /><•  /><International student issues:  /><Get advice on immigration, visas, living in the UK and how to prepare for your arrival. Find out about orientation and social events too. /><•  /><Wellbeing and mental health:  /><Get help for personal or emotional health difficulties, such as feeling low, anxious, or overwhelmed. /><•  /><Disabilities:  /><Get support if you have specific learning or processing difficulties, vision or hearing problems, long-term health conditions or reduced mobility (learn more under  /><Disability Support /><). /><•  /><Finance:  /><Get help with questions about fees, scholarships, debts and general funding. /><•  /><Housing:  /><Get support for dealing with general housing issues, finding accommodation and problems with landlords. /><Remember student support services are there for you when you’re struggling for any reason. Their job is to be helpful - so don’t hesitate to contact them. /><To learn more about student support visit: /><•  /><National Union of Students (NUS).  /><Find your Students' Union.  /><www.nus.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Support for me.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><The Student Room.  /><Support at university – the services that helped me most.  /><www.thestudentroom.co.uk /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admission Service (UCAS).  /><Getting undergraduate support.  /><www.ucas.com /><

Next State: <Navigate up /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Male health professional with stethoscope around his neck sits listening to a bearded male person in the foreground who has his back to the camera /><
 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><
 /><Content last updated: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review to be completed by: March 2026 /><Feedback: To help us improve the app for the benefit of other international students, please send us your comments and suggestions. /><Find contact details and a link to a short anonymous survey on the  /><Feedback page /><. /><Thank you for your help. /><Responsive image /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><If you need help or want to speak with someone about personal issues, your course or your health, your university or college offers various support services. Round 5: State: <Navigate up /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Male health professional with stethoscope around his neck sits listening to a bearded male person in the foreground who has his back to the camera /><
 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><
 /><Content last updated: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review to be completed by: March 2026 /><Feedback: To help us improve the app for the benefit of other international students, please send us your comments and suggestions. /><Find contact details and a link to a short anonymous survey on the  /><Feedback page /><. /><Thank you for your help. /><Responsive image /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><Feeling stressed, exhausted, or overwhelmed can make coping with everyday life and your studies difficult. Such feelings have to do with your mental health. Here we explain briefly what good mental health is and how to get support if needed. /><Good mental health involves feeling good about yourself and others, forming and maintaining healthy relationships, and being able to deal with - and overcome - challenges. /><When your mental health is poor, you may find it hard, or even impossible, to manage how you feel, think and act in response to emotional or other stresses. /><Important: If you feel anxious, low, panicky, isolated, stressed, lonely, homesick, overwhelmed or even suicidal (feeling so bad that you think life's not worth living anymore), remember that there are people at your university who understand, won’t judge, care about you, and want to do their best to help and support you (see below). It's perfectly okay to seek help when you need it. Together you can find solutions to improve your overall wellbeing and reduce any negative impact on your studies. /><Get help for mental health issues: /><•  /><Student support:  /><Your university will likely have a student wellbeing and welfare department whom you can ask for help, advice and assistance confidentially (which means they won't tell anyone else). Check your uni’s website or ask the international office for information about accessing these services. /><•  /><Outside organisations:  /><If you prefer to speak with someone from outside your university, various organisations are there to help (see links below). /><•  /><Your doctor (GP):  /><You can also speak with your GP about mental health issues - in confidence. /><If you're worried about a friend’s mental health, find advice on the  /><'Supporting a friend' /><page. /><Learn more about mental health and getting support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><The UK's student mental health charity.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Challenging mental health myths for international students.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Mental health support in the UK.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university.  /><If you need help or want to speak with someone about personal issues, your course or your health, your university or college offers various support services. Here we outline how these services can help and include useful links. /><Available services usually include (but may be called differently): /><•  /><Student Support (or Wellbeing)Service /><•  /><International Student Support team /><•  /><Students' Union /><•  /><University Medical (GP) Practice /><These services have trained advisers and professionals who are there to support and guide you (see below). /><You can find details about accessing support on your university’s and Students' Union’s websites. /><Important: Student support staff won't judge you, and they will keep what you tell them in strict confidence. They will understand your feelings, care about you, and want to do their best to support you. /><Your local student support teams can help you with things like: /><•  /><International student issues:  /><Get advice on immigration, visas, living in the UK and how to prepare for your arrival. Find out about orientation and social events too. /><•  /><Wellbeing and mental health:  /><Get help for personal or emotional health difficulties, such as feeling low, anxious, or overwhelmed. /><•  /><Disabilities:  /><Get support if you have specific learning or processing difficulties, vision or hearing problems, long-term health conditions or reduced mobility (learn more under  /><Disability Support /><). /><•  /><Finance:  /><Get help with questions about fees, scholarships, debts and general funding. /><•  /><Housing:  /><Get support for dealing with general housing issues, finding accommodation and problems with landlords. /><Remember student support services are there for you when you’re struggling for any reason. Round 4: State: <Navigate up /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Male health professional with stethoscope around his neck sits listening to a bearded male person in the foreground who has his back to the camera /><
 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><
