Round 3: State: <Navigate up /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Male health professional with stethoscope around his neck sits listening to a bearded male person in the foreground who has his back to the camera /><
 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><
 /><Content last updated: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review to be completed by: March 2026 /><Feedback: To help us improve the app for the benefit of other international students, please send us your comments and suggestions. /><Find contact details and a link to a short anonymous survey on the  /><Feedback page /><. /><Thank you for your help. /><Responsive image /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><If you need help or want to speak with someone about personal issues, your course or your health, your university or college offers various support services. Here we outline how these services can help and include useful links. /><Available services usually include (but may be called differently): /><•  /><Student Support (or Wellbeing)Service /><•  /><International Student Support team /><•  /><Students' Union /><•  /><University Medical (GP) Practice /><These services have trained advisers and professionals who are there to support and guide you (see below). /><You can find details about accessing support on your university’s and Students' Union’s websites. /><Important: Student support staff won't judge you, and they will keep what you tell them in strict confidence. They will understand your feelings, care about you, and want to do their best to support you. /><Your local student support teams can help you with things like: /><•  /><International student issues:  /><Get advice on immigration, visas, living in the UK and how to prepare for your arrival. Find out about orientation and social events too. /><•  /><Wellbeing and mental health:  /><Get help for personal or emotional health difficulties, such as feeling low, anxious, or overwhelmed. /><•  /><Disabilities:  /><Get support if you have specific learning or processing difficulties, vision or hearing problems, long-term health conditions or reduced mobility (learn more under  /><Disability Support /><). /><•  /><Finance:  /><Get help with questions about fees, scholarships, debts and general funding. /><•  /><Housing:  /><Get support for dealing with general housing issues, finding accommodation and problems with landlords. /><Remember student support services are there for you when you’re struggling for any reason. Round 0: State: <Navigate up /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Male health professional with stethoscope around his neck sits listening to a bearded male person in the foreground who has his back to the camera /><
 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><

 /><If you need medical assistance, various services are available under the  /><UK National Health Service (NHS) /><. The NHS is a complex organisation and can be challenging to navigate. Always refer to national and local guidance (see links below). /><Here are ways in which you can find medical information, help and advice (also see the page on  /><emergencies /><): /><•  /><NHS Website:  /><Find a wealth of medical and health information – including a symptom checker – on the NHS websites (links below). /><•  /><Call NHS 111:  /><Call this number for non-emergency medical help or advice or when unsure which service you need (available in England, Scotland and Wales). /><•  /><Ask a pharmacist:  /><You can find pharmacies on local high streets, in shopping areas or attached to GP surgeries. University GPs are experts in caring for students and will be the best place for medical advice and support.  /><If you need medical assistance, various services are available under the  /><UK National Health Service (NHS) /><. The NHS is a complex organisation and can be challenging to navigate. But to get the right care, you must know which services you can access and how to use them. So here we give you a quick introduction to accessing medical help. /><Important: The provision of health services can vary between the UK nations (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland). Always refer to national and local guidance (see links below). /><Here are ways in which you can find medical information, help and advice (also see the page on  /><emergencies /><): /><•  /><NHS Website:  /><Find a wealth of medical and health information – including a symptom checker – on the NHS websites (links below). /><•  /><Call NHS 111:  /><Call this number for non-emergency medical help or advice or when unsure which service you need (available in England, Scotland and Wales). /><•  /><Ask a pharmacist:  /><You can find pharmacies on local high streets, in shopping areas or attached to GP surgeries. Ask your pharmacist for advice on common and self-treatable health problems, such as sore throats, headaches, infections and travel issues. /><•  /><Contact your doctor (GP):  /><Register with a GP and contact your doctor's surgery when you're unwell or have another physical or mental health problem and it's not a life-threatening emergency. University GPs are experts in caring for students and will be the best place for medical advice and support. They also have local knowledge and understand university procedures. /><•  /><Visit a walk-in centre, minor injuries unit or urgent care centre:  /><Get treatment for minor illnesses and injuries such as cuts, sprains and rashes when you can't wait until your GP surgery opens. /><•  /><Visit A&E:  /><An Accident & Emergency (A&E) department deals with life-threatening emergencies and severe injuries. /><•  /><Call 999:  /><Call the emergency number when you or someone else is seriously injured or lives are at risk. /><Learn more about accessing services: /><•  /><NHS website:  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><Urgent and emergency care services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Symptom checker and local services for Wales.  /><https://111.wales.nhs.uk/ /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Health and healthcare.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><

Round 5: State: <Navigate up /><Accessing medical help /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Male health professional with stethoscope around his neck sits listening to a bearded male person in the foreground who has his back to the camera /><
 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><

Ask your pharmacist for advice on common and self-treatable health problems, such as sore throats, headaches, infections and travel issues. /><•  /><Contact your doctor (GP):  /><Register with a GP and contact your doctor's surgery when you're unwell or have another physical or mental health problem and it's not a life-threatening emergency. University GPs are experts in caring for students and will be the best place for medical advice and support. They also have local knowledge and understand university procedures. /><•  /><Visit a walk-in centre, minor injuries unit or urgent care centre:  /><Get treatment for minor illnesses and injuries such as cuts, sprains and rashes when you can't wait until your GP surgery opens. /><•  /><Visit A&E:  /><An Accident & Emergency (A&E) department deals with life-threatening emergencies and severe injuries. /><•  /><Call 999:  /><Call the emergency number when you or someone else is seriously injured or lives are at risk. /><Learn more about accessing services: /><•  /><NHS website:  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><Urgent and emergency care services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Symptom checker and local services for Wales.  /><https://111.wales.nhs.uk/ /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Health and healthcare.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><

 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><

 /><Student life can be challenging, and there may be times when you need help and support. So here we explain why speaking with someone is essential when you feel overly stressed or overwhelmed. /><Every student experiences normal ups and downs. /><But when, for example, life feels tough because you feel homesick or lonely, lag with your studies or worry about money, speaking with someone - a friend, family member, tutor, student support team member or health professional - can make a big difference. /><Important: Your university support services are there for you. They understand how you feel, care about you, and will want to do their best to help. Speaking with someone if you find life challenging and asking for support is not a sign of weakness. There's no shame in seeking support, even if it embarrasses you or doesn’t align with your culture. Be reassured - you won't be judged and won't waste people's time. Also, accessing university support is free. /><Unfortunately, it can sometimes take a while to find and get the help you need. If that's the case, keep speaking with people and try different things until you get the right support. Don't suffer in silence! /><Here's why seeking help and speaking with someone is so important when you're struggling: /><•  /><Feel relieved.  /><Talking about your problem can make you feel better and help you stop worrying. /><•  /><Understand the problem.  /><Exploring the reasons behind your difficulties can help you determine what may be happening. /><•  /><Find solutions.  /><Discover and discuss possible solutions you may not have thought of otherwise. /><•  /><Get back on track.  /><Return to your normal life faster to re-focus on the things that matter. /><•  /><Prevent future problems.  /><Build up new skills to help you manage other challenging situations in the future. /><Learn more about how to stay well at university and get support when you need it: /><•  /><British Council.  /><Support and guidance.  /><www.study-uk.britishcouncil.org /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Support for me.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Staying well and safe at university. Trigger Publishing.  /><triggerhub.org /><

 /><If you need medical assistance, various services are available under the  /><UK National Health Service (NHS) /><. The NHS is a complex organisation and can be challenging to navigate. But to get the right care, you must know which services you can access and how to use them. So here we give you a quick introduction to accessing medical help. /><Important: The provision of health services can vary between the UK nations (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland). Always refer to national and local guidance (see links below). /><Here are ways in which you can find medical information, help and advice (also see the page on  /><emergencies /><): /><•  /><NHS Website:  /><Find a wealth of medical and health information – including a symptom checker – on the NHS websites (links below). /><•  /><Call NHS 111:  /><Call this number for non-emergency medical help or advice or when unsure which service you need (available in England, Scotland and Wales). /><•  /><Ask a pharmacist:  /><You can find pharmacies on local high streets, in shopping areas or attached to GP surgeries. Ask your pharmacist for advice on common and self-treatable health problems, such as sore throats, headaches, infections and travel issues. /><•  /><Contact your doctor (GP):  /><Register with a GP and contact your doctor's surgery when you're unwell or have another physical or mental health problem and it's not a life-threatening emergency. University GPs are experts in caring for students and will be the best place for medical advice and support. They also have local knowledge and understand university procedures. /><•  /><Visit a walk-in centre, minor injuries unit or urgent care centre:  /><Get treatment for minor illnesses and injuries such as cuts, sprains and rashes when you can't wait until your GP surgery opens. /><•  /><Visit A&E:  /><An Accident & Emergency (A&E) department deals with life-threatening emergencies and severe injuries. /><•  /><Call 999:  /><Call the emergency number when you or someone else is seriously injured or lives are at risk. /><Learn more about accessing services: /><•  /><NHS website:  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><Urgent and emergency care services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Symptom checker and local services for Wales.  /><https://111.wales.nhs.uk/ /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Health and healthcare.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><

Round 2: State: <Navigate up /><Accessing medical help /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><The UK National Health Service (NHS) /><Male health professional with stethoscope around his neck sits listening to a bearded male person in the foreground who has his back to the camera /><
 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><

 /><Student life can be challenging, and there may be times when you need help and support. So here we explain why speaking with someone is essential when you feel overly stressed or overwhelmed. /><Every student experiences normal ups and downs. /><But when, for example, life feels tough because you feel homesick or lonely, lag with your studies or worry about money, speaking with someone - a friend, family member, tutor, student support team member or health professional - can make a big difference. /><Important: Your university support services are there for you. They understand how you feel, care about you, and will want to do their best to help. Speaking with someone if you find life challenging and asking for support is not a sign of weakness. There's no shame in seeking support, even if it embarrasses you or doesn’t align with your culture. Be reassured - you won't be judged and won't waste people's time. Also, accessing university support is free. /><Unfortunately, it can sometimes take a while to find and get the help you need. If that's the case, keep speaking with people and try different things until you get the right support.  /><Student life can be challenging, and there may be times when you need help and support. So here we explain why speaking with someone is essential when you feel overly stressed or overwhelmed. /><Every student experiences normal ups and downs. /><But when, for example, life feels tough because you feel homesick or lonely, lag with your studies or worry about money, speaking with someone - a friend, family member, tutor, student support team member or health professional - can make a big difference. /><Important: Your university support services are there for you. They understand how you feel, care about you, and will want to do their best to help. Speaking with someone if you find life challenging and asking for support is not a sign of weakness. There's no shame in seeking support, even if it embarrasses you or doesn’t align with your culture. Be reassured - you won't be judged and won't waste people's time. Also, accessing university support is free. /><Unfortunately, it can sometimes take a while to find and get the help you need. If that's the case, keep speaking with people and try different things until you get the right support. Don't suffer in silence! /><Here's why seeking help and speaking with someone is so important when you're struggling: /><•  /><Feel relieved.  /><Talking about your problem can make you feel better and help you stop worrying. /><•  /><Understand the problem.  /><Exploring the reasons behind your difficulties can help you determine what may be happening. /><•  /><Find solutions.  /><Discover and discuss possible solutions you may not have thought of otherwise. /><•  /><Get back on track.  /><Return to your normal life faster to re-focus on the things that matter. /><•  /><Prevent future problems.  /><Build up new skills to help you manage other challenging situations in the future. /><Learn more about how to stay well at university and get support when you need it: /><•  /><British Council.  /><Support and guidance.  /><www.study-uk.britishcouncil.org /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Support for me.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Thompson D.  /><Resourcefulness at university.  /><If you need medical assistance, various services are available under the  /><UK National Health Service (NHS) /><. The NHS is a complex organisation and can be challenging to navigate. But to get the right care, you must know which services you can access and how to use them. So here we give you a quick introduction to accessing medical help. /><Important: The provision of health services can vary between the UK nations (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland). Always refer to national and local guidance (see links below). /><Here are ways in which you can find medical information, help and advice (also see the page on  /><emergencies /><): /><•  /><NHS Website:  /><Find a wealth of medical and health information – including a symptom checker – on the NHS websites (links below). /><•  /><Call NHS 111:  /><Call this number for non-emergency medical help or advice or when unsure which service you need (available in England, Scotland and Wales). /><•  /><Ask a pharmacist:  /><You can find pharmacies on local high streets, in shopping areas or attached to GP surgeries. Ask your pharmacist for advice on common and self-treatable health problems, such as sore throats, headaches, infections and travel issues. /><•  /><Contact your doctor (GP):  /><Register with a GP and contact your doctor's surgery when you're unwell or have another physical or mental health problem and it's not a life-threatening emergency. University GPs are experts in caring for students and will be the best place for medical advice and support. They also have local knowledge and understand university procedures. /><•  /><Visit a walk-in centre, minor injuries unit or urgent care centre:  /><Get treatment for minor illnesses and injuries such as cuts, sprains and rashes when you can't wait until your GP surgery opens. /><•  /><Visit A&E:  /><An Accident & Emergency (A&E) department deals with life-threatening emergencies and severe injuries. /><•  /><Call 999:  /><Call the emergency number when you or someone else is seriously injured or lives are at risk. /><Learn more about accessing services: /><•  /><NHS website:  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><Urgent and emergency care services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Symptom checker and local services for Wales.  /><https://111.wales.nhs.uk/ /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Health and healthcare.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><

 /><The UK has a government-funded health system called the National Health Service (NHS). To get the right care, you must know which services you can access - and how they work. Here we give you a quick overview of available services for international and EU students. /><The NHS provides medical and health care services mostly free for UK residents. /><Note that NHS services vary between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. /><Important: Currently, if you have a Tier 4 student visa and are studying in the UK for six months or longer, or if you're a European Union (EU) student, you will have free access to many NHS services, including emergency treatment in hospital. You may need to pay a healthcare surcharge (called the ‘immigration health surcharge’ or IHS) as part of your immigration application. Remember that you may be required to present your biometric residence permit (BRP) when you access NHS services. Guidance may be subject to change, so always check government and NHS websites for details and updates (find useful links below). /><Here's a list of some of the services the NHS offers: /><•  /><Online information and advice:  /><The NHS Websites (links below) provide reliable health information and advice on hundreds of medical symptoms and conditions. /><•  /><Doctor's (GP) surgery:  /><Your first point of contact for most health issues and medical treatment. Your doctor, called a general practitioner (or GP), can refer you to the hospital if needed. Your GP surgery will provide several services, including contraception and sexual health. /><•  /><Dentist:  /><Get your teeth checked at least once a year. Not all dentists offer NHS services, and even if you receive treatment on the NHS, you may still need to contribute to the costs. /><•  /><Eye care:  /><High street opticians provide routine eye care services. Eye tests incur a charge, and prices for frames and lenses vary. /><•  /><Hospital:  /><If your GP refers you to the hospital, you may see a specialist doctor. Senior specialist doctors are called 'consultants'. /><•  /><Accident and Emergency (A&E) departments:  /><Larger hospitals will have A&E departments, usually open 24 hours a day. You will  /><not />< have to pay for emergency treatment. /><•  /><Emergency services:  /><In an emergency (and  /><only />< then), you can call the free emergency number 999 for an ambulance, the police or the fire service. /><Learn more about how the NHS works and how to access health services: /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Sympton checker and local services for Wales. /><111.wales.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><How the UK medical system works.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><•  /><UK Government Website (Gov.uk).  /><Pay for UK healthcare as part of your immigration application.  /><www.gov.uk /><

 /><Student life can be challenging, and there may be times when you need help and support. So here we explain why speaking with someone is essential when you feel overly stressed or overwhelmed. /><Every student experiences normal ups and downs. /><But when, for example, life feels tough because you feel homesick or lonely, lag with your studies or worry about money, speaking with someone - a friend, family member, tutor, student support team member or health professional - can make a big difference. /><Important: Your university support services are there for you. They understand how you feel, care about you, and will want to do their best to help. Speaking with someone if you find life challenging and asking for support is not a sign of weakness. There's no shame in seeking support, even if it embarrasses you or doesn’t align with your culture. Be reassured - you won't be judged and won't waste people's time. Also, accessing university support is free. /><Unfortunately, it can sometimes take a while to find and get the help you need. If that's the case, keep speaking with people and try different things until you get the right support.  /><Student life can be challenging, and there may be times when you need help and support. So here we explain why speaking with someone is essential when you feel overly stressed or overwhelmed. /><Every student experiences normal ups and downs. /><But when, for example, life feels tough because you feel homesick or lonely, lag with your studies or worry about money, speaking with someone - a friend, family member, tutor, student support team member or health professional - can make a big difference. /><Important: Your university support services are there for you.  /><Welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><Whether you face language barriers or culture shock, loneliness or homesickness, this app gives you all the information you need as an international or EU student in the UK to have the best possible experience. /><With practical and reassuring advice from experienced student advisers and international students, this app is packed with info on handling everyday challenges and life in the UK.  /><Welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><Whether you face language barriers or culture shock, loneliness or homesickness, this app gives you all the information you need as an international or EU student in the UK to have the best possible experience. /><With practical and reassuring advice from experienced student advisers and international students, this app is packed with info on handling everyday challenges and life in the UK.  /><Welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><Whether you face language barriers or culture shock, loneliness or homesickness, this app gives you all the information you need as an international or EU student in the UK to have the best possible experience. /><With practical and reassuring advice from experienced student advisers and international students, this app is packed with info on handling everyday challenges and life in the UK. Covering everything from how to prepare and settle in to opening a bank account and doing well in exams, this app is your one-stop guide to being an international student in the UK. /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn to be resilient and resourceful so you can feel well and in control. /><•  /><Find useful guidance at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to trusted information and support to help you thrive. /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health so you can enjoy uni life to the full. /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) so you can get the most out of your studies. /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes). /><About this app /><The app was created with international students and student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, in partnership with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review due by: March 2026 /><App developer: Expert Self Care Ltd, an accredited mobile health information app development company in Bristol, UK. /><Editor: Dr Knut Schroeder /><Get in touch /><Contact:  /><For comments, feedback and suggestions for improvements please email  /><knut.schroeder@expertselfcare.com /><. /><Telephone:  /><+44 (0) 117 924 3965 />< or  /><+44 (0) 7490 765 063 /><. /><Website:  /><www.expertselfcare.com /><

Find out about orientation and social events too. /><•  /><Wellbeing and mental health:  /><Get help for personal or emotional health difficulties, such as feeling low, anxious, or overwhelmed. /><•  /><Disabilities:  /><Get support if you have specific learning or processing difficulties, vision or hearing problems, long-term health conditions or reduced mobility (learn more under  /><Disability Support /><). /><•  /><Finance:  /><Get help with questions about fees, scholarships, debts and general funding. /><•  /><Housing:  /><Get support for dealing with general housing issues, finding accommodation and problems with landlords. /><Remember student support services are there for you when you’re struggling for any reason.  /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only. Whilst we have used all reasonable care in pulling together and presenting the information, we cannot guarantee its accuracy. Where you find medical or health information on this app, you must not rely on the information provided in this app as an alternative to medical or health advice from your university student support service, doctor or other professional healthcare provider. /><•  /><Age:  /><This app is aimed at readers 17+ years of age. /><•  /><External websites:  /><This app contains links to other websites. While we have chosen to include only links that we believe to be safe and useful, please be aware that we are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of such other websites. /><•  /><Privacy:  /><You do not have to provide any personal or sign-up information to use this app. But please be aware that we collect anonymous data about how people use the app. We use this data to better understand, for example, which topics users access the most. This helps us evaluate the effectiveness of the content, plan new features, and measure the number of users certain topic attract. Be assured, this data is not linked to your identity, and we will not collect any personal data. /><•  /><Tracking codes:  /><Some links to external websites of our partner organisations (such as colleges, universities and charities) may contain anonymous tracking codes (UTM codes). These codes enable the website owners to track where their website traffic comes from. This data is entirely anonymous and not linked to your identity. Its only purpose is to measure the overall traffic generated by the app to help evaluate, for example, the effectiveness of awareness campaigns. /><•  /><Terms & conditions:  /><For further details, please refer to our full terms and conditions, which you can access through the 'About' tab on the home screen. If you do not agree to our terms and conditions, please do no longer use this app. /><•  /><Feedback:  /><To help us improve the app or point out errors (such as broken links) please send us your feedback, comments and suggestions (find contact details in the 'About' section). /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only. While we have chosen to include only links that we believe to be safe and useful, please be aware that we are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of such other websites. /><•  /><Privacy:  /><You do not have to provide any personal or sign-up information to use this app. But please be aware that we collect anonymous data about how people use the app. We use this data to better understand, for example, which topics users access the most. Be assured, this data is not linked to your identity, and we will not collect any personal data. /><•  /><Tracking codes:  /><Some links to external websites of our partner organisations (such as colleges, universities and charities) may contain anonymous tracking codes (UTM codes).  /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only.  /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only. Whilst we have used all reasonable care in pulling together and presenting the information, we cannot guarantee its accuracy. Where you find medical or health information on this app, you must not rely on the information provided in this app as an alternative to medical or health advice from your university student support service, doctor or other professional healthcare provider. /><•  /><Age:  /><This app is aimed at readers 17+ years of age. /><•  /><External websites:  /><This app contains links to other websites. While we have chosen to include only links that we believe to be safe and useful, please be aware that we are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of such other websites. /><•  /><Privacy:  /><You do not have to provide any personal or sign-up information to use this app. But please be aware that we collect anonymous data about how people use the app. We use this data to better understand, for example, which topics users access the most. This helps us evaluate the effectiveness of the content, plan new features, and measure the number of users certain topic attract. Be assured, this data is not linked to your identity, and we will not collect any personal data. /><•  /><Tracking codes:  /><Some links to external websites of our partner organisations (such as colleges, universities and charities) may contain anonymous tracking codes (UTM codes). These codes enable the website owners to track where their website traffic comes from. This data is entirely anonymous and not linked to your identity. Its only purpose is to measure the overall traffic generated by the app to help evaluate, for example, the effectiveness of awareness campaigns. /><•  /><Terms & conditions:  /><For further details, please refer to our full terms and conditions, which you can access through the 'About' tab on the home screen. If you do not agree to our terms and conditions, please do no longer use this app. /><•  /><Feedback:  /><To help us improve the app or point out errors (such as broken links) please send us your feedback, comments and suggestions (find contact details in the 'About' section). /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only. Whilst we have used all reasonable care in pulling together and presenting the information, we cannot guarantee its accuracy. Where you find medical or health information on this app, you must not rely on the information provided in this app as an alternative to medical or health advice from your university student support service, doctor or other professional healthcare provider. /><•  /><Age:  /><This app is aimed at readers 17+ years of age. /><•  /><External websites:  /><This app contains links to other websites. While we have chosen to include only links that we believe to be safe and useful, please be aware that we are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of such other websites. /><•  /><Privacy:  /><You do not have to provide any personal or sign-up information to use this app. But please be aware that we collect anonymous data about how people use the app. We use this data to better understand, for example, which topics users access the most. This helps us evaluate the effectiveness of the content, plan new features, and measure the number of users certain topic attract. Be assured, this data is not linked to your identity, and we will not collect any personal data. /><•  /><Tracking codes:  /><Some links to external websites of our partner organisations (such as colleges, universities and charities) may contain anonymous tracking codes (UTM codes). These codes enable the website owners to track where their website traffic comes from. This data is entirely anonymous and not linked to your identity. Its only purpose is to measure the overall traffic generated by the app to help evaluate, for example, the effectiveness of awareness campaigns. /><•  /><Terms & conditions:  /><For further details, please refer to our full terms and conditions, which you can access through the 'About' tab on the home screen. If you do not agree to our terms and conditions, please do no longer use this app. /><•  /><Feedback:  /><To help us improve the app or point out errors (such as broken links) please send us your feedback, comments and suggestions (find contact details in the 'About' section). /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only. Whilst we have used all reasonable care in pulling together and presenting the information, we cannot guarantee its accuracy. Where you find medical or health information on this app, you must not rely on the information provided in this app as an alternative to medical or health advice from your university student support service, doctor or other professional healthcare provider. /><•  /><Age:  /><This app is aimed at readers 17+ years of age. /><•  /><External websites:  /><This app contains links to other websites. While we have chosen to include only links that we believe to be safe and useful, please be aware that we are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of such other websites. /><•  /><Privacy:  /><You do not have to provide any personal or sign-up information to use this app. But please be aware that we collect anonymous data about how people use the app. We use this data to better understand, for example, which topics users access the most. This helps us evaluate the effectiveness of the content, plan new features, and measure the number of users certain topic attract. Be assured, this data is not linked to your identity, and we will not collect any personal data. /><•  /><Tracking codes:  /><Some links to external websites of our partner organisations (such as colleges, universities and charities) may contain anonymous tracking codes (UTM codes). These codes enable the website owners to track where their website traffic comes from. This data is entirely anonymous and not linked to your identity. Its only purpose is to measure the overall traffic generated by the app to help evaluate, for example, the effectiveness of awareness campaigns. /><•  /><Terms & conditions:  /><For further details, please refer to our full terms and conditions, which you can access through the 'About' tab on the home screen. If you do not agree to our terms and conditions, please do no longer use this app. /><•  /><Feedback:  /><To help us improve the app or point out errors (such as broken links) please send us your feedback, comments and suggestions (find contact details in the 'About' section). /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only. Whilst we have used all reasonable care in pulling together and presenting the information, we cannot guarantee its accuracy. Where you find medical or health information on this app, you must not rely on the information provided in this app as an alternative to medical or health advice from your university student support service, doctor or other professional healthcare provider. /><•  /><Age:  /><This app is aimed at readers 17+ years of age. /><•  /><External websites:  /><This app contains links to other websites. While we have chosen to include only links that we believe to be safe and useful, please be aware that we are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of such other websites. /><•  /><Privacy:  /><You do not have to provide any personal or sign-up information to use this app. But please be aware that we collect anonymous data about how people use the app. We use this data to better understand, for example, which topics users access the most. This helps us evaluate the effectiveness of the content, plan new features, and measure the number of users certain topic attract. Be assured, this data is not linked to your identity, and we will not collect any personal data. /><•  /><Tracking codes:  /><Some links to external websites of our partner organisations (such as colleges, universities and charities) may contain anonymous tracking codes (UTM codes). These codes enable the website owners to track where their website traffic comes from. This data is entirely anonymous and not linked to your identity. Its only purpose is to measure the overall traffic generated by the app to help evaluate, for example, the effectiveness of awareness campaigns. /><•  /><Terms & conditions:  /><For further details, please refer to our full terms and conditions, which you can access through the 'About' tab on the home screen. If you do not agree to our terms and conditions, please do no longer use this app. /><•  /><Feedback:  /><To help us improve the app or point out errors (such as broken links) please send us your feedback, comments and suggestions (find contact details in the 'About' section). /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only. Whilst we have used all reasonable care in pulling together and presenting the information, we cannot guarantee its accuracy. Where you find medical or health information on this app, you must not rely on the information provided in this app as an alternative to medical or health advice from your university student support service, doctor or other professional healthcare provider. /><•  /><Age:  /><This app is aimed at readers 17+ years of age. /><•  /><External websites:  /><This app contains links to other websites. While we have chosen to include only links that we believe to be safe and useful, please be aware that we are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of such other websites. /><•  /><Privacy:  /><You do not have to provide any personal or sign-up information to use this app. But please be aware that we collect anonymous data about how people use the app. We use this data to better understand, for example, which topics users access the most. This helps us evaluate the effectiveness of the content, plan new features, and measure the number of users certain topic attract. Be assured, this data is not linked to your identity, and we will not collect any personal data. /><•  /><Tracking codes:  /><Some links to external websites of our partner organisations (such as colleges, universities and charities) may contain anonymous tracking codes (UTM codes). These codes enable the website owners to track where their website traffic comes from. This data is entirely anonymous and not linked to your identity. Its only purpose is to measure the overall traffic generated by the app to help evaluate, for example, the effectiveness of awareness campaigns. /><•  /><Terms & conditions:  /><For further details, please refer to our full terms and conditions, which you can access through the 'About' tab on the home screen. If you do not agree to our terms and conditions, please do no longer use this app. /><•  /><Feedback:  /><To help us improve the app or point out errors (such as broken links) please send us your feedback, comments and suggestions (find contact details in the 'About' section). /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>
