 /><PIF Tick logo /><Hello, and welcome to the International Student App (UK)! /><If you're an international or European Union (EU) student in the UK, this app - co-produced by people who support international students and international students themselves - helps you settle and thrive at your new university or college. /><We know that moving to the UK as a new student can be challenging. When you're facing things like academic pressures, language barriers, culture shock, loneliness, or homesickness, it's all too easy to feel stressed - even overwhelmed. /><But if you're struggling and could do with a little bit of help, we know that you might find it hard to approach people about this because, for example: /><•  /><you feel embarrassed /><•  /><it's not done in your culture /><•  /><you don't know that support is available, or how to access it /><That's where the International Student App (UK) comes to the rescue. The app gives you instant access to lots of useful information, practical tips and links to useful resources - all in one single place. It enables you to better handle common challenges, get support if you need it, and as a result, flourish at university. /><Here's how you can benefit from using this app: /><•  /><Improve your wellbeing.  /><Learn how to become resilient and resourceful as a student - feel great and more in control /><•  /><Find help at the touch of a button.  /><Instantly access hundreds of links to information and support /><•  /><Give your health and wellbeing a boost.  /><Know what you can do yourself to look after your physical and mental health /><•  /><Get instant access to practical tips.  /><Develop your study skills, learn how to improve your English, and find out how to navigate the UK National Health Service (NHS) /><•  /><Access local service directories.  /><Customise the app to easily access local information and support - even when offline (if your university or college subscribes) /><Date the app was last checked and reviewed: 10 May 2022 /><Next review due by: 10 May 2024 /><Who created the app? /><The app was created by  /><Expert Self Care Ltd /><(an accredited health information app producer) together with the international student support teams at the  /><University of the West of England (UWE Bristol) />< and the  /><University of Lincoln /><, with international students themselves, and with  /><Student Minds /><, the UK's Student Mental Health Charity. /><Responsive image /><Using this app /><Before you start using the app, please be aware of the following (for your own safety and security): /><•  /><Accuracy of information:  /><The information on this app is meant for general guidance only. Whilst we have used all reasonable care in pulling together and presenting the information, we cannot guarantee its accuracy. Where you find medical or health information on this app, you must not rely on the information provided in this app as an alternative to medical or health advice from your university student support service, doctor or other professional healthcare provider. /><•  /><Age:  /><This app is aimed at readers 17+ years of age. /><•  /><External websites:  /><This app contains links to other websites. While we have chosen to include only links that we believe to be safe and useful, please be aware that we are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of such other websites. /><•  /><Privacy:  /><You do not have to provide any personal or sign-up information to use this app. But please be aware that we collect anonymous data about how people use the app. We use this data to better understand, for example, which topics users access the most. This helps us evaluate the effectiveness of the content, plan new features, and measure the number of users certain topic attract. Be assured, this data is not linked to your identity, and we will not collect any personal data. /><•  /><Tracking codes:  /><Some links to external websites of our partner organisations (such as colleges, universities and charities) may contain anonymous tracking codes (UTM codes). These codes enable the website owners to track where their website traffic comes from. This data is entirely anonymous and not linked to your identity. Its only purpose is to measure the overall traffic generated by the app to help evaluate, for example, the effectiveness of awareness campaigns. /><•  /><Terms & conditions:  /><For further details, please refer to our full terms and conditions, which you can access through the 'About' tab on the home screen. If you do not agree to our terms and conditions, please do no longer use this app. /><•  /><Feedback:  /><To help us improve the app or point out errors (such as broken links) please send us your feedback, comments and suggestions (find contact details in the 'About' section). /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

 /><If you have a long-term illness, disability or mental health issue, you might benefit from 'peer support'. Peer support is about getting help from fellow students who have been in a similar situation or share the same experience. Here we explain how peer support works and how to access it. /><Peer support can be helpful because the people you speak with understand what you might be feeling and going through. /><Peer support can take different forms, from mentoring to peer-assisted study sessions and buddy schemes. /><To find out if a peer support scheme is available at your college or university, look online on your university's website, and contact your student support team or Students' Union. /><Tip: Local international student centres may be available at your place of study, offering a place to meet other international students, social events and peer support. /><You can benefit from peer support in various ways: /><•  /><Support:  /><Feel supported, build new relationships and find your identity in a safe and caring environment. /><•  /><Understanding:  /><Discuss and share emotional stresses, and feel understood. /><•  /><Control:  /><Overcome stigma, get back control over your life and become more confident by tackling false ideas, such as that you're 'not good enough' or 'don't deserve help'. /><•  /><Feelings and thoughts:  /><Tackle negative and unhelpful emotions and thoughts. Learn to see your situation in a different light, so that you no longer feel so bad about it. /><•  /><Hope:  /><Stay motivated while you're getting better, be inspired by others and feel more hopeful. /><Tip: Consider providing peer support yourself if you feel able to do so. It may give you a confidence boost and turn past negative experiences into something positive. /><Learn more about peer support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Peer support for student mental health.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Looking after a mate.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Time to change.  /><Ask twice.  /><www.time-to-change /><

 /><UK universities recognise that faith, belief and spirituality play an important part in your life - and that separation from your faith community at home can feel daunting and unsettling. So here we give tips for finding faith and spiritual support inside and outside your university or college. /><Important: Most universities have multi-faith chaplaincies and student faith organisations that provide information and spiritual support. They often offer opportunities to drop in and talk, and they oversee the universities' religious activities. Also, consider connecting with local faith communities outside the university. Regardless of your background, your university support team will be there for you. /><Britain has a long multicultural history. This means you can find communities and places of worship of all the major religions almost anywhere – including public places such as airports and hospitals. /><Here are some tips for finding faith and spiritual support and information: /><•  /><University website:  /><Look for information on faith and spirituality, which you may find under 'chaplaincy'. /><•  /><Welcome events:  /><The chaplaincy may organise events for international students in and out of term time, allowing you to meet people and discuss issues relating to your faith and life at university. /><•  /><Food:  /><Most university cities and towns will have shops offering food to cater to the needs of different faiths. /><•  /><Students' Union:  /><Your Students' Union is likely to have religious societies, which you will be welcome to join. /><•  /><Prayer rooms:  /><Multi-faith prayer rooms and rooms for silence and quiet reflection may be available at your university (often open 24 hours a day). /><•  /><Religious items:  /><You are free to wear pieces of religious dress, such as hijabs, turbans or yarmulkes at university. /><•  /><Holidays:  /><You can celebrate religious festivals, such as Diwali, Eid, Hannukah and Christmas. /><Learn more about faith and spiritual support at university: /><•  /><Al Islam - Ahmadiyya Muslim Students Association (AMSA).  /><https://www.alislam.org/ /><•  /><British Council.  /><Religion. in the UK - practising your faith.  /><www.study-uk.britishcouncil.org /><•  /><British Organisation of Sikh Students.  /><www.boss-uk.org /><•  /><National Hindu Students' Forum.  /><www.nhsf.org.uk /><•  /><Network of Buddhist Organisations.  /><www.nbo.org.uk /><•  /><Student Christian Movement.  /><www.movement.org.uk /><•  /><The Union of Jewish Students.  /><www.ujs.org.uk /><

 /><If you have a long-term illness, disability or mental health issue, you might benefit from 'peer support'. Peer support is about getting help from fellow students who have been in a similar situation or share the same experience. Here we explain how peer support works and how to access it. /><Peer support can be helpful because the people you speak with understand what you might be feeling and going through. /><Peer support can take different forms, from mentoring to peer-assisted study sessions and buddy schemes. /><To find out if a peer support scheme is available at your college or university, look online on your university's website, and contact your student support team or Students' Union. /><Tip: Local international student centres may be available at your place of study, offering a place to meet other international students, social events and peer support. /><You can benefit from peer support in various ways: /><•  /><Support:  /><Feel supported, build new relationships and find your identity in a safe and caring environment. /><•  /><Understanding:  /><Discuss and share emotional stresses, and feel understood. /><•  /><Control:  /><Overcome stigma, get back control over your life and become more confident by tackling false ideas, such as that you're 'not good enough' or 'don't deserve help'. /><•  /><Feelings and thoughts:  /><Tackle negative and unhelpful emotions and thoughts. Learn to see your situation in a different light, so that you no longer feel so bad about it. /><•  /><Hope:  /><Stay motivated while you're getting better, be inspired by others and feel more hopeful. /><Tip: Consider providing peer support yourself if you feel able to do so. It may give you a confidence boost and turn past negative experiences into something positive. /><Learn more about peer support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Peer support for student mental health.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Looking after a mate.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Time to change.  /><Ask twice.  /><www.time-to-change /><

Round 5: State: <Navigate up /><Faith and spirituality /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><Faith support /><Group of four students sitting on grass taking a selfie while smiling into the camera /><
 /><UK universities recognise that faith, belief and spirituality play an important part in your life - and that separation from your faith community at home can feel daunting and unsettling. So here we give tips for finding faith and spiritual support inside and outside your university or college. /><Important: Most universities have multi-faith chaplaincies and student faith organisations that provide information and spiritual support. They often offer opportunities to drop in and talk, and they oversee the universities' religious activities. Also, consider connecting with local faith communities outside the university. Regardless of your background, your university support team will be there for you. /><Britain has a long multicultural history. This means you can find communities and places of worship of all the major religions almost anywhere – including public places such as airports and hospitals. /><Here are some tips for finding faith and spiritual support and information: /><•  /><University website:  /><Look for information on faith and spirituality, which you may find under 'chaplaincy'. /><•  /><Welcome events:  /><The chaplaincy may organise events for international students in and out of term time, allowing you to meet people and discuss issues relating to your faith and life at university. /><•  /><Food:  /><Most university cities and towns will have shops offering food to cater to the needs of different faiths. /><•  /><Students' Union:  /><Your Students' Union is likely to have religious societies, which you will be welcome to join. /><•  /><Prayer rooms:  /><Multi-faith prayer rooms and rooms for silence and quiet reflection may be available at your university (often open 24 hours a day). /><•  /><Religious items:  /><You are free to wear pieces of religious dress, such as hijabs, turbans or yarmulkes at university. /><•  /><Holidays:  /><You can celebrate religious festivals, such as Diwali, Eid, Hannukah and Christmas. /><Learn more about faith and spiritual support at university: /><•  /><Al Islam - Ahmadiyya Muslim Students Association (AMSA).  /><https://www.alislam.org/ /><•  /><British Council.  /><Religion. in the UK - practising your faith.  /><www.study-uk.britishcouncil.org /><•  /><British Organisation of Sikh Students.  /><www.boss-uk.org /><•  /><National Hindu Students' Forum.  /><www.nhsf.org.uk /><•  /><Network of Buddhist Organisations.  /><www.nbo.org.uk /><•  /><Student Christian Movement.  /><www.movement.org.uk /><•  /><The Union of Jewish Students.  /><www.ujs.org.uk /><
 /><Content last updated: March 2023 /><Next scheduled review to be completed by: March 2026 /><Feedback: To help us improve the app for the benefit of other international students, please send us your comments and suggestions. /><Find contact details and a link to a short anonymous survey on the  /><Feedback page /><. /><Thank you for your help. /><Responsive image /><   /></Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template>

Next State: <Navigate up /><Student support services /><Favourite /><Back /><Forward /><Expert Self Care - Student Health - Template><   /><Student support services /><Female and male person sitting at computer desk wearing earpieces with microphones, smiling and waving into the camera /><
 /><If you need help or want to speak with someone about personal issues, your course or your health, your university or college offers various support services. Here we outline how these services can help and include useful links. /><Available services usually include (but may be called differently): /><•  /><Student Support (or Wellbeing)Service /><•  /><International Student Support team /><•  /><Students' Union /><•  /><University Medical (GP) Practice /><These services have trained advisers and professionals who are there to support and guide you (see below). /><You can find details about accessing support on your university’s and Students' Union’s websites. /><Important: Student support staff won't judge you, and they will keep what you tell them in strict confidence. They will understand your feelings, care about you, and want to do their best to support you. /><Your local student support teams can help you with things like: /><•  /><International student issues:  /><Get advice on immigration, visas, living in the UK and how to prepare for your arrival. Find out about orientation and social events too. /><•  /><Wellbeing and mental health:  /><Get help for personal or emotional health difficulties, such as feeling low, anxious, or overwhelmed. /><•  /><Disabilities:  /><Get support if you have specific learning or processing difficulties, vision or hearing problems, long-term health conditions or reduced mobility (learn more under  /><Disability Support /><). /><•  /><Finance:  /><Get help with questions about fees, scholarships, debts and general funding. /><•  /><Housing:  /><Get support for dealing with general housing issues, finding accommodation and problems with landlords. /><Remember student support services are there for you when you’re struggling for any reason.  /><If you have a long-term illness, disability or mental health issue, you might benefit from 'peer support'. Peer support is about getting help from fellow students who have been in a similar situation or share the same experience. Here we explain how peer support works and how to access it. /><Peer support can be helpful because the people you speak with understand what you might be feeling and going through. /><Peer support can take different forms, from mentoring to peer-assisted study sessions and buddy schemes. /><To find out if a peer support scheme is available at your college or university, look online on your university's website, and contact your student support team or Students' Union. /><Tip: Local international student centres may be available at your place of study, offering a place to meet other international students, social events and peer support. /><You can benefit from peer support in various ways: /><•  /><Support:  /><Feel supported, build new relationships and find your identity in a safe and caring environment. /><•  /><Understanding:  /><Discuss and share emotional stresses, and feel understood. /><•  /><Control:  /><Overcome stigma, get back control over your life and become more confident by tackling false ideas, such as that you're 'not good enough' or 'don't deserve help'. /><•  /><Feelings and thoughts:  /><Tackle negative and unhelpful emotions and thoughts. Learn to see your situation in a different light, so that you no longer feel so bad about it. /><•  /><Hope:  /><Stay motivated while you're getting better, be inspired by others and feel more hopeful. /><Tip: Consider providing peer support yourself if you feel able to do so. It may give you a confidence boost and turn past negative experiences into something positive. /><Learn more about peer support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Peer support for student mental health.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Looking after a mate.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Time to change.  /><Ask twice.  /><www.time-to-change /><

 /><UK universities recognise that faith, belief and spirituality play an important part in your life - and that separation from your faith community at home can feel daunting and unsettling. So here we give tips for finding faith and spiritual support inside and outside your university or college. /><Important: Most universities have multi-faith chaplaincies and student faith organisations that provide information and spiritual support. They often offer opportunities to drop in and talk, and they oversee the universities' religious activities. Also, consider connecting with local faith communities outside the university. Regardless of your background, your university support team will be there for you. /><Britain has a long multicultural history. This means you can find communities and places of worship of all the major religions almost anywhere – including public places such as airports and hospitals. /><Here are some tips for finding faith and spiritual support and information: /><•  /><University website:  /><Look for information on faith and spirituality, which you may find under 'chaplaincy'. /><•  /><Welcome events:  /><The chaplaincy may organise events for international students in and out of term time, allowing you to meet people and discuss issues relating to your faith and life at university. /><•  /><Food:  /><Most university cities and towns will have shops offering food to cater to the needs of different faiths. /><•  /><Students' Union:  /><Your Students' Union is likely to have religious societies, which you will be welcome to join. /><•  /><Prayer rooms:  /><Multi-faith prayer rooms and rooms for silence and quiet reflection may be available at your university (often open 24 hours a day). /><•  /><Religious items:  /><You are free to wear pieces of religious dress, such as hijabs, turbans or yarmulkes at university. /><•  /><Holidays:  /><You can celebrate religious festivals, such as Diwali, Eid, Hannukah and Christmas. /><Learn more about faith and spiritual support at university: /><•  /><Al Islam - Ahmadiyya Muslim Students Association (AMSA).  /><https://www.alislam.org/ /><•  /><British Council.  /><Religion. in the UK - practising your faith.  /><www.study-uk.britishcouncil.org /><•  /><British Organisation of Sikh Students.  /><www.boss-uk.org /><•  /><National Hindu Students' Forum.  /><www.nhsf.org.uk /><•  /><Network of Buddhist Organisations.  /><www.nbo.org.uk /><•  /><Student Christian Movement.  /><www.movement.org.uk /><•  /><The Union of Jewish Students.  /><www.ujs.org.uk /><

 /><If you need help or want to speak with someone about personal issues, your course or your health, your university or college offers various support services. Here we outline how these services can help and include useful links. /><Available services usually include (but may be called differently): /><•  /><Student Support (or Wellbeing)Service /><•  /><International Student Support team /><•  /><Students' Union /><•  /><University Medical (GP) Practice /><These services have trained advisers and professionals who are there to support and guide you (see below). /><You can find details about accessing support on your university’s and Students' Union’s websites. /><Important: Student support staff won't judge you, and they will keep what you tell them in strict confidence. They will understand your feelings, care about you, and want to do their best to support you. /><Your local student support teams can help you with things like: /><•  /><International student issues:  /><Get advice on immigration, visas, living in the UK and how to prepare for your arrival. Find out about orientation and social events too. /><•  /><Wellbeing and mental health:  /><Get help for personal or emotional health difficulties, such as feeling low, anxious, or overwhelmed. /><•  /><Disabilities:  /><Get support if you have specific learning or processing difficulties, vision or hearing problems, long-term health conditions or reduced mobility (learn more under  /><Disability Support /><). /><•  /><Finance:  /><Get help with questions about fees, scholarships, debts and general funding. /><•  /><Housing:  /><Get support for dealing with general housing issues, finding accommodation and problems with landlords. /><Remember student support services are there for you when you’re struggling for any reason. Their job is to be helpful - so don’t hesitate to contact them. /><To learn more about student support visit: /><•  /><National Union of Students (NUS).  /><Find your Students' Union.  /><www.nus.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Support for me.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><The Student Room.  /><Support at university – the services that helped me most.  /><www.thestudentroom.co.uk /><•  /><Universities and Colleges Admission Service (UCAS).  /><Getting undergraduate support.  /><www.ucas.com /><

 /><If you have a long-term illness, disability or mental health issue, you might benefit from 'peer support'. Peer support is about getting help from fellow students who have been in a similar situation or share the same experience. Here we explain how peer support works and how to access it. /><Peer support can be helpful because the people you speak with understand what you might be feeling and going through. /><Peer support can take different forms, from mentoring to peer-assisted study sessions and buddy schemes. /><To find out if a peer support scheme is available at your college or university, look online on your university's website, and contact your student support team or Students' Union. /><Tip: Local international student centres may be available at your place of study, offering a place to meet other international students, social events and peer support. /><You can benefit from peer support in various ways: /><•  /><Support:  /><Feel supported, build new relationships and find your identity in a safe and caring environment. /><•  /><Understanding:  /><Discuss and share emotional stresses, and feel understood. /><•  /><Control:  /><Overcome stigma, get back control over your life and become more confident by tackling false ideas, such as that you're 'not good enough' or 'don't deserve help'. /><•  /><Feelings and thoughts:  /><Tackle negative and unhelpful emotions and thoughts. Learn to see your situation in a different light, so that you no longer feel so bad about it. /><•  /><Hope:  /><Stay motivated while you're getting better, be inspired by others and feel more hopeful. /><Tip: Consider providing peer support yourself if you feel able to do so. It may give you a confidence boost and turn past negative experiences into something positive. /><Learn more about peer support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Peer support for student mental health.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Looking after a mate.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Time to change.  /><Ask twice.  /><www.time-to-change /><

 /><UK universities recognise that faith, belief and spirituality play an important part in your life - and that separation from your faith community at home can feel daunting and unsettling. So here we give tips for finding faith and spiritual support inside and outside your university or college. /><Important: Most universities have multi-faith chaplaincies and student faith organisations that provide information and spiritual support. They often offer opportunities to drop in and talk, and they oversee the universities' religious activities. Also, consider connecting with local faith communities outside the university. Regardless of your background, your university support team will be there for you. /><Britain has a long multicultural history. This means you can find communities and places of worship of all the major religions almost anywhere – including public places such as airports and hospitals. /><Here are some tips for finding faith and spiritual support and information: /><•  /><University website:  /><Look for information on faith and spirituality, which you may find under 'chaplaincy'. /><•  /><Welcome events:  /><The chaplaincy may organise events for international students in and out of term time, allowing you to meet people and discuss issues relating to your faith and life at university. /><•  /><Food:  /><Most university cities and towns will have shops offering food to cater to the needs of different faiths. /><•  /><Students' Union:  /><Your Students' Union is likely to have religious societies, which you will be welcome to join. /><•  /><Prayer rooms:  /><Multi-faith prayer rooms and rooms for silence and quiet reflection may be available at your university (often open 24 hours a day). /><•  /><Religious items:  /><You are free to wear pieces of religious dress, such as hijabs, turbans or yarmulkes at university. /><•  /><Holidays:  /><You can celebrate religious festivals, such as Diwali, Eid, Hannukah and Christmas. /><Learn more about faith and spiritual support at university: /><•  /><Al Islam - Ahmadiyya Muslim Students Association (AMSA).  /><https://www.alislam.org/ /><•  /><British Council.  /><Religion. in the UK - practising your faith.  /><www.study-uk.britishcouncil.org /><•  /><British Organisation of Sikh Students.  /><www.boss-uk.org /><•  /><National Hindu Students' Forum.  /><www.nhsf.org.uk /><•  /><Network of Buddhist Organisations.  /><www.nbo.org.uk /><•  /><Student Christian Movement.  /><www.movement.org.uk /><•  /><The Union of Jewish Students.  /><www.ujs.org.uk /><

 /><If you need help or want to speak with someone about personal issues, your course or your health, your university or college offers various support services. They will understand your feelings, care about you, and want to do their best to support you. /><Your local student support teams can help you with things like: /><•  /><International student issues:  /><Get advice on immigration, visas, living in the UK and how to prepare for your arrival.  /><UK universities recognise that faith, belief and spirituality play an important part in your life - and that separation from your faith community at home can feel daunting and unsettling. So here we give tips for finding faith and spiritual support inside and outside your university or college. /><Important: Most universities have multi-faith chaplaincies and student faith organisations that provide information and spiritual support. They often offer opportunities to drop in and talk, and they oversee the universities' religious activities. Also, consider connecting with local faith communities outside the university. Regardless of your background, your university support team will be there for you. /><Britain has a long multicultural history. This means you can find communities and places of worship of all the major religions almost anywhere – including public places such as airports and hospitals. /><Here are some tips for finding faith and spiritual support and information: /><•  /><University website:  /><Look for information on faith and spirituality, which you may find under 'chaplaincy'. /><•  /><Welcome events:  /><The chaplaincy may organise events for international students in and out of term time, allowing you to meet people and discuss issues relating to your faith and life at university. /><•  /><Food:  /><Most university cities and towns will have shops offering food to cater to the needs of different faiths. /><•  /><Students' Union:  /><Your Students' Union is likely to have religious societies, which you will be welcome to join. /><•  /><Prayer rooms:  /><Multi-faith prayer rooms and rooms for silence and quiet reflection may be available at your university (often open 24 hours a day). /><•  /><Religious items:  /><You are free to wear pieces of religious dress, such as hijabs, turbans or yarmulkes at university. /><•  /><Holidays:  /><You can celebrate religious festivals, such as Diwali, Eid, Hannukah and Christmas. /><Learn more about faith and spiritual support at university: /><•  /><Al Islam - Ahmadiyya Muslim Students Association (AMSA).  /><https://www.alislam.org/ /><•  /><British Council.  /><Religion. in the UK - practising your faith.  /><www.study-uk.britishcouncil.org /><•  /><British Organisation of Sikh Students.  /><www.boss-uk.org /><•  /><National Hindu Students' Forum.  /><www.nhsf.org.uk /><•  /><Network of Buddhist Organisations.  /><www.nbo.org.uk /><•  /><Student Christian Movement.  /><www.movement.org.uk /><•  /><The Union of Jewish Students.  /><www.ujs.org.uk /><

 /><If you need medical assistance, various services are available under the  /><UK National Health Service (NHS) /><. The NHS is a complex organisation and can be challenging to navigate. But to get the right care, you must know which services you can access and how to use them. So here we give you a quick introduction to accessing medical help. /><Important: The provision of health services can vary between the UK nations (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland). Always refer to national and local guidance (see links below). /><Here are ways in which you can find medical information, help and advice (also see the page on  /><emergencies /><): /><•  /><NHS Website:  /><Find a wealth of medical and health information – including a symptom checker – on the NHS websites (links below). /><•  /><Call NHS 111:  /><Call this number for non-emergency medical help or advice or when unsure which service you need (available in England, Scotland and Wales). /><•  /><Ask a pharmacist:  /><You can find pharmacies on local high streets, in shopping areas or attached to GP surgeries. Ask your pharmacist for advice on common and self-treatable health problems, such as sore throats, headaches, infections and travel issues. /><•  /><Contact your doctor (GP):  /><Register with a GP and contact your doctor's surgery when you're unwell or have another physical or mental health problem and it's not a life-threatening emergency. University GPs are experts in caring for students and will be the best place for medical advice and support. They also have local knowledge and understand university procedures. /><•  /><Visit a walk-in centre, minor injuries unit or urgent care centre:  /><Get treatment for minor illnesses and injuries such as cuts, sprains and rashes when you can't wait until your GP surgery opens. /><•  /><Visit A&E:  /><An Accident & Emergency (A&E) department deals with life-threatening emergencies and severe injuries. /><•  /><Call 999:  /><Call the emergency number when you or someone else is seriously injured or lives are at risk. /><Learn more about accessing services: /><•  /><NHS website:  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><Urgent and emergency care services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Symptom checker and local services for Wales.  /><https://111.wales.nhs.uk/ /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Health and healthcare.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><

Here we explain how peer support works and how to access it. /><Peer support can be helpful because the people you speak with understand what you might be feeling and going through. /><Peer support can take different forms, from mentoring to peer-assisted study sessions and buddy schemes. /><To find out if a peer support scheme is available at your college or university, look online on your university's website, and contact your student support team or Students' Union. /><Tip: Local international student centres may be available at your place of study, offering a place to meet other international students, social events and peer support. /><You can benefit from peer support in various ways: /><•  /><Support:  /><Feel supported, build new relationships and find your identity in a safe and caring environment. /><•  /><Understanding:  /><Discuss and share emotional stresses, and feel understood. /><•  /><Control:  /><Overcome stigma, get back control over your life and become more confident by tackling false ideas, such as that you're 'not good enough' or 'don't deserve help'. /><•  /><Feelings and thoughts:  /><Tackle negative and unhelpful emotions and thoughts. Learn to see your situation in a different light, so that you no longer feel so bad about it. /><•  /><Hope:  /><Stay motivated while you're getting better, be inspired by others and feel more hopeful. /><Tip: Consider providing peer support yourself if you feel able to do so.  /><If you have a long-term illness, disability or mental health issue, you might benefit from 'peer support'. Peer support is about getting help from fellow students who have been in a similar situation or share the same experience. Here we explain how peer support works and how to access it. /><Peer support can be helpful because the people you speak with understand what you might be feeling and going through. /><Peer support can take different forms, from mentoring to peer-assisted study sessions and buddy schemes. /><To find out if a peer support scheme is available at your college or university, look online on your university's website, and contact your student support team or Students' Union. /><Tip: Local international student centres may be available at your place of study, offering a place to meet other international students, social events and peer support. /><You can benefit from peer support in various ways: /><•  /><Support:  /><Feel supported, build new relationships and find your identity in a safe and caring environment. /><•  /><Understanding:  /><Discuss and share emotional stresses, and feel understood. /><•  /><Control:  /><Overcome stigma, get back control over your life and become more confident by tackling false ideas, such as that you're 'not good enough' or 'don't deserve help'. /><•  /><Feelings and thoughts:  /><Tackle negative and unhelpful emotions and thoughts. Learn to see your situation in a different light, so that you no longer feel so bad about it. /><•  /><Hope:  /><Stay motivated while you're getting better, be inspired by others and feel more hopeful. /><Tip: Consider providing peer support yourself if you feel able to do so. It may give you a confidence boost and turn past negative experiences into something positive. /><Learn more about peer support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Peer support for student mental health.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Looking after a mate.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Time to change.  /><Ask twice.  /><www.time-to-change /><

 /><If you need medical assistance, various services are available under the  /><UK National Health Service (NHS) /><. The NHS is a complex organisation and can be challenging to navigate.  /><If you have a long-term illness, disability or mental health issue, you might benefit from 'peer support'. Peer support is about getting help from fellow students who have been in a similar situation or share the same experience. Here we explain how peer support works and how to access it. /><Peer support can be helpful because the people you speak with understand what you might be feeling and going through. /><Peer support can take different forms, from mentoring to peer-assisted study sessions and buddy schemes. /><To find out if a peer support scheme is available at your college or university, look online on your university's website, and contact your student support team or Students' Union. /><Tip: Local international student centres may be available at your place of study, offering a place to meet other international students, social events and peer support. /><You can benefit from peer support in various ways: /><•  /><Support:  /><Feel supported, build new relationships and find your identity in a safe and caring environment. /><•  /><Understanding:  /><Discuss and share emotional stresses, and feel understood. /><•  /><Control:  /><Overcome stigma, get back control over your life and become more confident by tackling false ideas, such as that you're 'not good enough' or 'don't deserve help'. /><•  /><Feelings and thoughts:  /><Tackle negative and unhelpful emotions and thoughts. Learn to see your situation in a different light, so that you no longer feel so bad about it. /><•  /><Hope:  /><Stay motivated while you're getting better, be inspired by others and feel more hopeful. /><Tip: Consider providing peer support yourself if you feel able to do so. It may give you a confidence boost and turn past negative experiences into something positive. /><Learn more about peer support: /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Peer support for student mental health.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Student Minds.  /><Looking after a mate.  /><www.studentminds.org.uk /><•  /><Time to change.  /><Ask twice.  /><www.time-to-change /><

 /><If you need medical assistance, various services are available under the  /><UK National Health Service (NHS) /><. The NHS is a complex organisation and can be challenging to navigate. But to get the right care, you must know which services you can access and how to use them. So here we give you a quick introduction to accessing medical help. /><Important: The provision of health services can vary between the UK nations (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland). Always refer to national and local guidance (see links below). /><Here are ways in which you can find medical information, help and advice (also see the page on  /><emergencies /><): /><•  /><NHS Website:  /><Find a wealth of medical and health information – including a symptom checker – on the NHS websites (links below). /><•  /><Call NHS 111:  /><Call this number for non-emergency medical help or advice or when unsure which service you need (available in England, Scotland and Wales). /><•  /><Ask a pharmacist:  /><You can find pharmacies on local high streets, in shopping areas or attached to GP surgeries. Ask your pharmacist for advice on common and self-treatable health problems, such as sore throats, headaches, infections and travel issues. /><•  /><Contact your doctor (GP):  /><Register with a GP and contact your doctor's surgery when you're unwell or have another physical or mental health problem and it's not a life-threatening emergency. University GPs are experts in caring for students and will be the best place for medical advice and support. They also have local knowledge and understand university procedures. /><•  /><Visit a walk-in centre, minor injuries unit or urgent care centre:  /><Get treatment for minor illnesses and injuries such as cuts, sprains and rashes when you can't wait until your GP surgery opens. /><•  /><Visit A&E:  /><An Accident & Emergency (A&E) department deals with life-threatening emergencies and severe injuries. /><•  /><Call 999:  /><Call the emergency number when you or someone else is seriously injured or lives are at risk. /><Learn more about accessing services: /><•  /><NHS website:  /><NHS Services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS website (England).  /><Urgent and emergency care services.  /><www.nhs.uk /><•  /><NHS 111 Wales.  /><Symptom checker and local services for Wales.  /><https://111.wales.nhs.uk/ /><•  /><NHS 24 (Scotland).  /><Health information for Scotland.  /><www.nhs24.scot /><•  /><Health and Social Care Online (Northern Ireland).  /><www.online.hscni.net /><•  /><UK Council for International Student Affairs (UKCISA).  /><Health and healthcare.  /><www.ukcisa.org.uk /><
